Name: An Echo in the Bone: A Novel (Outlander)

ReviewList.Text: Wow - I cannot believe I waited years for this!  I love the Outlander series and feel utterly letdown after reading this book.  First, the pacing was terrible.  The first 2/3 of the book were slow and Jamie and Claire were barely mentioned until the second half.  Once it does finally get going the ending is slammed in with no real ending at all.  At first, I thought my Kindle didn't download the whole thing.  The editing is awful.  There is WAY too much about John Grey and other incidental characters we don't really care about.  But the absolute limit to my patience came when DG had Claire and John having sex just weeks after Jaime's "supposed" death!  What the f@%!*  Are you kidding me!?  I was disgusted and angry.  That was so unbelievably out of character for Claire (and Lord John) and cheapend the whole book (as if it wasn't bad enough already.)  I really hope that in DG's next installment that she gets back to the relationship of Jaime and Claire and their adventures.  Their love story is what got people hooked on the series in the first place.  This book was a complete departure from everything that was good in the earlier books of the series and not worth the read.

Each of the books in the Outlander series causes havoc in my life because I can't put them down until I am done reading the whole book. Unfortunately, this book did not follow suite, taking me several weeks to read as it was completely disappointing and boring. Talk about choppy chapters, way too many characters that weren't developed and history that droned on and on with information that I learned back in elementary school. Where was the passion of the characters from the previous books and why were Jamie and Claire given only minor roles? This book was an introduction to sell her new Lord Grey book coming out in 2010 - come on! What about the inconsistencies from the previous books - I kept going back to them to make sure I hadn't forgotten a story. Jamie on the ocean not having seasickness; Claire sleeping with Lord Grey - get real; and taking ¾ of the book to get them to Scotland and then only spending a few pages on that part of the story. Who wrote this book and better yet, who edited it. Wish I could get my money back!!

Not a novel itself, just one more chapter in the series. Not a story with a beginning and an end. Deceitful. Too many cliffhangers left open and just a few answers. The four plots make the narration really slow. Only for real fans. I'm dissapointed, even angry with the author for the sudden end.

I have devoured all of the previous Outlander series books, but this one was quite a different book.  It felt as if it was written by a completely different author.  The story line dragged on and on seemingly with no point.  Some sections were so boring that I just fast forwarded heaps of pages.  As dedicated readers invested in Jamie & Claire and then who grew to love Brianna & Roger, why is most of this book now about William and Lord John Grey?  Where I would read the other books in a few days or a week tops, this book took me more than 4 months to wade through.  As others have mentioned, the storyline is confusing with times not matching up, many detailed sections of the book seem absolutely pointless and I have a hard time understanding why I should care about William or Grey.  Both of their parts should have been minimal in this book with more focus on Jamie & Claire and Brianna & Roger.  I like the idea of the letter reading and the two sets of main characters being in different times and yet still communicating so to speak, but the focus of this book seemed to be on William and Grey and I found those sections both painfully difficult to read and quite boring.  I am quite disillusioned by this series now.  I hope her next book makes up for this dismal interjection in the series.
Tired of Gabaldon's meandering. It is time to end this series. I am the only one left in my reading group even trying to stick with this series to the end. Very disappointing. Reads like patch work.

I purchased this book before there were any reviews and I just got done reading it, well sort of. Like others have said, the ending is abrupt and leaves you wondering where the rest of the book is hiding. The ending is really not an ending at all. It seems to be so much more like the ending of a chapter not an eight hundred page novel. I really disliked all the focus on other characters. Bri and Roger were fine but their story line was dull with no real action til near the end. However, that short amount of story line was never resolved in this book. The entire William-Lord Grey-Jamie triangle of suspense was overly drawn out. In all, the lack of resolution to any major story line was a complete disappointment. The book was interesting enough and well written and I enjoyed most of it, even the somewhat too long historical first half. But when I got to the end, I just couldn't believe it. How could anyone, the editor, friends reading it, a proofreader etc. think that this is an acceptable ending to a novel? Yes, indeed it sets you up for reading the next book in the series, but I would have purchased and read that new book even if Diana had resolved 100% of the outstanding cliff hangers in this book. There was no need to end it in such a way as to force us to buy the next book simply to find the answers to the issues raised in this book. In fact, I do plan to buy the next book because I feel compelled to find resolution for these unresolved plots. BUT, and this is a big but, my enthusiasm for this series is dampened now. I feel cheated by this book. I real feel that this book is all about creating a market and revenue for the next book. If this type of ending were to be repeated in the next book, I am currently inclined walk away from this series.

I have loved each and everyone of these books, from the Outlander thru the series and could hardly wait for the latest.  I agree, it took a little getting into but I can't fault the author's choice to bring in more story lines using the characters she has introduced throughout the series, and making Lord John Grey a central character in this book only makes sense considering her separate novels devoted to John Grey.  I had a wonderful time reading the book but....it seemed this 828 page book was actually a 1600 page book arbitrarily cut in two.  Since she has warned us it takes her five years to write each novel I am afraid I may not make it until I find out how she resolves all the hanging stories introduced in the final fifty pages.  I assume there will be a follow up book and I am relieved she did not kill off any essential characters in this book (I was very concerned she might kill Jamie and end the series with this book.)  This is obviously not the end of the series, but its end seemed manipulative, and reminded me more of a soap opera or the tickler at the season final of a TV series to make certain we tune in next season.  Diana Gabaldon has not done this in any of the previous books.  They each completed their story lines and tied up loose ends.  I don't know why she made a different decision this time.  I wish she would explain.

As a huge fan of the series I never thought I'd be so disappointed in this book.  Several inconsistencies in the book were simply jarring (as mentioned by others).  Also, the most cheaply contrived scene ever written by DG- not to give away too much- but one major character lost in a swamp MIRACULOUSLY found and saved by another major character in the book. I'm all for suspension of disbelief but seriously?  Also, I get cliff-hangers sell sequels but when conversations are just stopped mid-thought and the minor story lines are the only ones concluded-I feel angry and ripped off.  Unfortunately, I paid full price for this book.  DISAPPOINTED, disillusioned....(the reviews are funny by the Kindle readers who thought the last chapters were missing...they were)

I was thrilled when I saw that "Echo in the Bone" had been released.  i devoured Gbaldon's previous novels, and when I read "Echo" i felt like I had been duped.  Who wrote this book?  It's pretty clear by how crap it is, that she had some assistants put together information on the Revolutionary War, then just went through quickly and strung it together putting in too many plots that go nowhere. Yes, we know the battles were long and awful, history books are full of the gory details and we don't need you to retell it posing as fiction. And Claire, who went through the stones and pined for jamie for how many years was a little casual about his death,"oh, he's dead, I guess I'll just go get drunk and shag his gay boyfriend" ...no way, that would never happen.  And then, oh I guess Jamie's alive and oops, we were just playing about. I NEVER thought i would ever give her less that full marks, but seriously, Diana?  You are truly the best writer I have ever read, (and i have a degree in Literature) so this was a slap in the face.  If you're bored with the series, just end it.  Don't put us through that again.

I've loved all of the Outlander series and could not wait for Echo in the Bone to come out. I think Diana Gabaldon is a fabulous writer. Having said this, I was so disappointed with this book. I love Jaime and Claire's story and felt that they were reduced to being minor characters in this installment. The book was a very slow read. Especially Lord John's letters to William. I don't care for either character and found myself flipping through the pages to find Jaime and Claire. (This should have been re-titled as a Lord John book). There were too many characters and too many confusing plot lines. The ending was rushed and packed full of cliffhangers that didn't ring true. Claire handing out pamphlets was barely touched on and all of a sudden she is going to be arrested and has to marry Lord John to stay out of prison? Bizarre. And she ends up sleeping with him? A character with whom she has always been jealous of and who has been her adversary throughout the series? Shocking, yes. True to character? I don't think so. Where were Ian and Fergus and Marsali when Jaime supposedly died? No memorial, no service? They just went along with Claire marrying John? It's almost as if the editor said, the book is getting too long, let's end it with a punch. Like an action movie - lots of explosions with little substance.

Love me some Diana but this was a mess. When I got to the end I felt like I should shake the book and see if the missing chapters would fall out. It had how many story lines and not one of them felt resolved at the end. I feel like I just read half of a book. I've come across this with series of some other good authors lately and am starting to wonder if it is some sort of sales stunt. I guess there is a fine line between "leave them wanting more" and "leave them feeling ripped off."

When I first read Outlander, I quite literally called in sick to work 3 days in a row just to keep reading - and I was the English Lit teacher.  Aside from Pride & Prejudice and Gone with the Wind, Outlander is my favorite book.  I reread it at least twice a year.  Within 20 minutes of finishing Outlander, I was knee deep in Dragonfly.  Followed by Voyager.  Then, there was a drop in the quality of the story.  It was less about Jamie & Claire, but I accepted more characters helped things progress.  By A Breath I was no longer loving the storyline, but having read thousands and thousands of pages, I owed it to myself to keep going.  Then, along came Echo.  Oh, Diana what happened?  This book was so disjointed and boring.  I skipped large sections just to force myself to keep trudging onwards hoping for the end and trying to figure out what was going on with characters I only felt apathy towards.  After waiting for 4 years for this book to come out, I could hardly believe I was putting it down again and again.  That it took weeks to finish.  That I didn't even want to finish it.  It was truly awful.  I felt no interest in any of the characters given hundreds of pages of plot.  I searched, to no avail, for Jamie Fraser and Claire in this story that pretends to be about them.  I'll buy the final book just to have the matched set, but I don't know if I will even be able to open the cover.  This should have ended at Voyager.  It's been on a serious decline until it's become Echo - watered down drivel.

I have been a fan of many of the past Outlander books.  I picked up this paperback and agree with several other reviews.  The book is over 1,000 pages and very difficult to just hold in your  hand.  Besides the physical issue the content is boring.  Too many story lines, , time lines, characters, and laborious descriptions.  The first few books of this series flowed better and kept you reading and wanting to know what happens to Jamie and Claire.  Then the series added more generations, story  lines and became more difficult and unpleasant to get through.  Sorry, this book so bogged me  down that this is my last one.

I loved the first of this series, very much liked some of the others, but "An Echo in the Bone" was a huge disappointment.  It rambles and rambles, telling a bunch of different (sometimes interesting) adventures that more or less are related. And then it stops. I'm sure we are supposed to breathlessly await what happens to everyone next -- but I now frankly don't care. Where was the editor???

I have read all the previous novels in this series and I'm so disappointed in this one.  It jumps all around from time period to continent and back.  I almost started a spreadsheet to keep track of the characters.  It never did catch my interest but I kept reading anyway only to get to an ending that was not an ending at all.  Very frustrating.

This book is tedious,tedious,tedious!With a lot of unnecessary dialog and characters.To say it is choppy,is an understatement.In Gabaldon's attempts to convince everyone that her books are in fact not romances,she has effectively killed the "epic" romance between Jamie and Claire.Do not waste your money on this book,wait until you can get it from the library.

I too was a rabid Diana fan.  I missed out on half of a trip around the British Isles because my travel companion suggested the first book to me and I picked it up at the gift shop at Culloden.  I was hooked from page one.  That being said, I really wish the series ended after book three or four.  The plot lines are getting more and more far fetched and/or repetative.  How many times do we follow William as he wandered around lost?  The likelihood of all the chance meetings??  Please!  And this is from someone who swallowed the whole time travel premise without batting an eye.  References made to the more recent books are lost on me even though I dutifully read them.  I could pretty much recite the first three books if not word for word at least chronologically by scene/encounter.  I'm sorry, Diana, but you lost me.  I stopped reading after several half hearted attempts since Fall (I, too, had it pre-ordered) and moved on to Donati's latest.  Not finished yet, but at least I'm still interested.

I am a huge fan of the Outlander series and Diana's Lord John books as well, so I was glad to see all of the characters together again in one book. The majority of the book felt like those that had come before. Then the tornado hit. In the last couple of chapters, it seemed as though Diana was writing a parody of one of her own books. It felt like she realized she didn't have much room left, and so threw the rest of the story * splat * in my face.  Very many things happened in very little time, with the characters acting very out of character. I realize the entire work is fiction, and some of the other scenes were not very likely either, but this was ridiculous. And while I can appreciate a good cliff hanger, the way she left the storyline involving Brianna, Roger and Jem was an insult.  I normally can't wait until the next book comes out, and reread the others in the meantime. This time I realized I don't really care when the next one comes out.

I was SO disappointed with this book.  As a die-hard Outlander fan, and Jamie fanatic, I REALLY REALLY REALLY want to know how it ends.  An Echo in the Bone was 600 pgs of historical facts, that I learned in elementary school and didn't really want to rehash, followed by approximately 200 pgs of AWESOME story.  I wish Diana had started with the last 1/4 of the book and gone for 800+ pgs from there.  Seems like she just couldn't hit her stride until 3/4 of the way through writing but instead of editing the first 600 pgs out she thought "oh, well, longer than 800 pgs is too much, better stop here".  Really annoying, and I'm not happy about having to wait for the next book.  I highly recommend not buying An Echo in the Bone until the next one comes out, and then reading both together.

I have loved every one of the DG books and used to think that she was a wonderful writer.  However, after reading Echo in the Bone, I am so disappointed in her.  I feel that she has left the book hanging to be sure we all rush out to buy the next one in the series.  Well, her fans would have done that anyway without all the loose ends that she left.  I am so annoyed at her disrespect for her readers that I am doubtful if I will read another one of her books.

Loved all the Outlander books so much that I broke my own rule about buying a hardcover cover book (they are just too big and expensive) and splashed out and bought the hardcover... Now i wish I waited for the paperback... This is the weakest book in the series.  I love the Jamie & Clair storyline and there was just so little of this in the book.  I am fed up with Lord John - wish he would go far away and stay there.  Roll on book no 8.

As the next installment of Diana Gabaldon's wildly successful Highlander series, the current, "Echo in the Bone" should be titled, "Annoy Me to the Bone".  Does this woman have an editor?  I literally slapped the book when finally done with the 8 millionth page, screaming, "You didn't!  How could you do this to me?"  The "cliffhanger" nee "let me rope you in to make sure you buy the next behemoth" is unbelieveable and with so many dangling particples of story line as to resemble a giant squid engulfing the next sucker.  So many superfluous characters, scenes, excrutiating details, I yearned for a red editing pencil myself.  The book is not for first time readers (nee suckers) of Ms. Gabaldon's.  I wanted to love this book.  Being from Boston, and a Revolutionary War history buff, it was fun to read some of the details of southern and Philadelphia imaginings but I found myself skipping pages (and pages, and pages) of useless minutiae, and wanderings of other characters--William, Rachel, Lord John Gray.  Frequently, the dialogue between characters is so unbelieveable, and at times unnecessarily crude between main characters Jamie and Clair to be laughable (not in a good way).  Wait for the next one before getting this, and be ready to self edit by skipping whole parts of chapters.  Maybe I'll get Ms. Gabaldon an editor for her Christmas stocking.

I'm an avid fan of the Outlander series and was so anxious for Echo to be released. That said, this book was, for me, a 'jump the shark' moment for the series. (If that's possible for a book.) Not that I found the different character stories difficult to follow. I didn't. I just did not care. Entirely too much Lord John. I'm not a fan and I don't wish to spend money reading so much about him. If I did, I'd buy a Lord John book.Jamie and Claire lack that absorption in each other that we all love so much. Claire takes off his finger with nary a fuss about it. Very unlike Claire. She fussed more over Lizzie than Jamie.The editors missed things that had been covered in the past books. Jenny was no longer angry with Claire and yet in Echo she's almost venomous. Jamie having indeed seen William after the age of 12. We're completely left out of a conversation between Bree and Lord John concerning her families true origins. But it's implied that it happened.Then we got into the ridiculous with Claire and Lord John. I'd sooner have believed Claire hopped into bed with a woman.Truly disappointing after such a wait. I can't bring myself to reread it as I have the other 6 books. I was not pulled into the story to the point that I lost track of time.Hopefully the next book will have clarity and much, much more time with our beloved Claire and Jamie. And save the Lord John series for Lord John. This is Jamie and Claire's story!I'd give it two stars, but I'm feeling generous.

As a huge fan of this series, I was so excited to finally get the book. What a disappointment.  To enjoy the series, one must suspend disbelief and Gabaldon has allowed us to do that with her superb storytelling.  However, this book goes too far. The multiple plotlines are dizzying with so many characters that I practically had to keep a chart.  And, the lord john/percy plotline was so convoluted that I quit trying to decipher all the hidden innuendos and gunned through those passages without really reading them.  Bree and family were dull and the Buccleigh/Cameron plotline was ludicrous. Another bad idea was connecting all these characters in bizzare fashion. Dottie to Dr. Hunter, Rob Cameron to Geillis Duncan, William to Simon Fraser to Jamie...ugh! This book felt like a launching pad for at least four  more separate series and I am deeply disappointed. I was hoping to reconnect with Jamie and Claire, but their nonstop, hair-raising, swashbuckling adventures left me in a state of constant disbelief. I was not upset about paying more for this book until it I finished it.

I waited and watched the authors website for years as to when this book would be released.  I was so excited that I pre-ordered! Wow...what a disappointment! I was frustrated throughout the first half of the book as I felt I was reading a Lord John novel.  I kept thinking, okay, Jamie and Claire are in here somewhere!  Without giving away any of the content of the story, I feel that at least 2/3 of this book could have been omitted.  Lots of run on....too many cliff hangers and the overall story just felt "forced" and lacked the typical flow and creativity that I Gabaldon has exhibited in the past.  Let's hope the next one is better.

I have been a die hard Gabaldon fan.  I adore Jamie and Claire.  I have waited with great anticipation for this volume and I have never been more disappointed.  It seems that Diana Gabaldon has stopped writing and resigned herself to selling books.  The beginning of the book is laborious and I hated the intermingling of four different stories that bounced you hither and yon.  The first 700 pages were slow and shallow with only glimpses of the people we love.  Unfortunately in this writing, these characters were mere shells of themselves.  I wanted to KNOW William like I KNOW Brianna and Ian but it just didn't happen.  His character was not fleshed out in the least.  I wanted Laoghaire to die a bloody death.  She DID try to kill Claire and she DID shoot Jamie and call Brianna all sorts of names but nooooooooo...Jamie needs to see her to quell his jealousy.  Give me a break!!!!  I only wish I had stopped after the first 700 pages.  The last 25 or so are hard to describe.  Chapters were a page and a half long as if the author was sitting there saying..."Okay, I have to do something sensational with this character and then I have to do something sensational with this character and the whole thing was an incoherent shuffle.  I cried.  I beat the book.  I threw the book.  I don't even want to put it on the shelf with the others.  Lord John has his own series.  LET HIM STAY THERE!!!  Color me disappointed...

While "Outlander" is my all time favorite book, I had pretty much the same reaction as others to this sequel.  After waiting so long to pick up the exciting and touching story of Jamie & Claire, I found myself wishing a lot less of Lord John was in the book. With all the romantic characters in these books, to make a complete series of Lord John books, to me, is a loss, I just cannot get into him. It seems everytime An Echo got going, it turned away to another direction and I wondered about the long drawn out Ticonderoga, the  ship to ship to ship ocean voyage and some of William's postings in the war to this & that General story line. While I always devour the books and also immerse myself (often hate to return to the present) & always shed a tear and a closed throat, I did feel led willy nilly at times, and hated the ending(if you could actually say there was an ending.  Indeed, re reading the entire series will have to be done again(such a sacrifice) when the next installment comes out. I can say I always find something in the re-reading I missed the previous 6 times, but yes, I am getting confused by sooooo many characters and yes, the jumping back & forth  of chapters from  Lord John, William ,Jamie, Claire, Ian & all the others. I do enjoy the Roger & Brianna storyline, Love the Young Ian storyline (my personal choice for a new book series), and while I know Jamie & Claire will eventually end, I hate to see the final " The End" to 2 such wonderfull characters!!

The majority of ECHO is plagued with too many scenes that do nothing to move the story along, painstaking details of battles, medical procedures, random strangers, one detour after another, only to ultimately fast forward over the most vital and interesting bits.  The entire last quarter of the book, which should have been the focus of the story, is rushed and jarring (they FINALLY make it to Scotland and are there for what seems to be 20 pages?), with actions so weirdly out of character for Claire you'll wonder if someone else wrote the ending.  The Brianna and Roger storyline was dull, with nothing really happening to them or with them until the very end.  I can't understand why DG would spend hundreds of pages on so much stuff that got tedious when she obviously had a lot of other interesting plot lines she could have worked with.  I also counted no less than 7 points of view and too, too many cliffhangers and mysteries that fail to intrigue.  I love Jamie & Claire, but I'd like to see the story wrap up.

I have hung on faithfully to this series, but I must say by book four I was starting to see a habit with this author of being a little too detailed about some subjects and sometimes not getting to the point at all.  I staggered through this seventh book believing that I would feel some sort of closure at its conclusion.  Instead it seems to me that the author intends to continue the series.  She has an awesome talent and I would sincerely love to see her focus her attentions on a new character in perhaps a different era, such as the old west.  If you are new to the series, books 1 through 3 will serve you well and leave you a great feeling when are you done with these stories.  Be prepared to be forgiving throuought the other stories, however, as they are more of a history review and a study in annoying behaviors than anything else.

I was so excited to dive into this book.  Such a very long wait from the last one in the series.  But I was so disapointed in 99% of the story.  The last 80 pages are just about the only excitement in the story.  I have never been interested in reading the "Lord John" books and felt that I was being forced into reading one.  The story just plods along so slowly it is frustrating.  Then suddenly near the end she throws up some interesting story lines then ends the book.  I don't get it. Most of the interesting parts of this book could have been condensed to 150 or less pages.  So Sad!!!!  The worst part is I really want to find out how the story ends but will have to wait another 3 years for her to write another book.

"Spoiler Alert"  I have been counting down the years, months and days until the books release.  I literally was waiting outside the book store 10 minutes before it opened because their has never been a better serious than Outlander, however echo in the bone has tarnished it's perfect reputation.  Diana is a fabulous writer, but this book was too chaotic.  It felt so rushed and disjointed and their was just not enough about Jaime and Claire.  I realize they are aging and that possibly Diana would like to have some characters to create a spin off, but trying to focus on 7 different perspectives (Claire, Jaime, Ian, Roger, Brianna, William, and Lord John) in one book was way too much.  I did enjoy learning more about William and Ian, and I thought the Roger/Brianna storyline was very captivating and interesting, but they needed to be more elaborated upon.  Honestly the book could have used another 800 pages just to give the reader a more in depth look at every storyline. My biggest disappointment was the reaction Claire gave when she thought Jaime had drowned in the Ocean.  It almost seemed like someone else had written that part of the book as their were so few pages to describe Claire's devastation.  The old Claire would not have been able to survive without him, but instead she attends a party and then sleeps with Lord John with little regret???  Then the book ends as if you are only half way through, with every storyline completely in the air.  I think it is cruel to leave her faithful fans in waiting for another 2 or 3 years, I wish the book could have tied up the loose ends, but still leaving us wanting more, as opposed to how I felt which was a little angry and ripped off.  I love Diana and everything she has done up until this point so I feel bad being so negative, I just look forward to the second part of this book and some clarity into the fate of each character.

I love this series but this book was a major disappointment. Horrors of horrors, I am not a "Brianna" fan and thought if Diana wanted us to know about her after her "leaving" she should start another series. SPOILER ALERT.........she has turned Claire into a serial adulterer and REALLY days after Jamie's "disappearance", she is in another man's arms and THAT MAN!! I have not read the John Grey books because I am not a fan. I think Diana rushed this book and abandoned what her readers were drawn to....the Jamie/Claire aspect amid historical references. There have always been portions of Diana's books that are hard to read and make me pause but that happened constantly with this book. Hoping next book is more "Gabaldonesque" and less disjointed.

Like many reviewers I've been a fan of the series for many years. But I'm having so much trouble reading this one that I wanted to read other reviews. I'm not alone! Story not engrossing, too much about Willie whom I have not been enticed to care about, sex scenes seem gratuitous not lovely and I did NOT need descriptions of naked guy parts as they swam in the cold pool. Too much medical detail, too much jumping around. Concur that EDITING was sorely needed! Book needs to be shorter and tighter and focus on the magic of Claire and Jamie. If she can't do that, then series should end. If there's another book, I will NOT buy it. I can read it from the library and it will probably be too long like this one. Will just skim to get to the end. NOT how I thought I'd feel about a Gabaldon book. Gets two stars because of nostalgia for Claire and Jamie and the series as a whole.

Yup I skimmed too! Couldn't believe it-skimming through an Outlander book? Very bad sign. I agree with previous reviewers comment that this series should have ended with Voyager. I really never got into the books set in America. My favorite scenes in these were at River Run. Guess I don't get into the pioneer stuff and I detest reading about hunting, killing and skinning animals, and Brianna (Gag) Hunter Goddess. I know that's how it was but it doesn't mean I want to read about it in detail. The books after Voyager seem like a different series that I could live without. I didn't even buy A Breath of Snow and Ashes. I waited until I got it on cd at the library. It wasn't as bad as I'd feared it would be and actually would have been another good place to end the series. This latest long convoluted addition borders on the bizarre and rediculous. To be fair I doubt Ms Gabaldon realized the impact Outlander would have and is now scrambling to tie the whole thing together with explanations of how the stones work (do we really CARE that much as long as the story is good?)and everyone ending up being related in some way (Fergus and the Comte St. Germaine and maybe Claire). Agree with too much Lord John. I've read a couple of his stories and couldn't get into them but the authour is sure in love with him. Found the Hunters boring and annoying. Liked the Arch Bugg story line. Dottie boring. Willie boring. Ticonderoga boring. Benedict Arnold was interesting but then he up and vanished after two pages. And what's up with these messages from Frank... I never bought that thing of the grave marker. Just gets more and more impluasible and silly. The worst is that Ms. Gabaldon has lost the character of Claire. I don't like her any longer. Detest Brianna and I used to like Roger but can't stand him now for marrying Bree. And what was up with Jamie at the end. Did he go batty? I could believe the Claire spy angle if she did it after hearing about Jamie's death, maybe out a sense of despair but why on earth would she bother otherwise? She knows the Americans will win the war with or without her help. Oh, and how many people has she told now about being a time traveler? She's lucky she hasn't been sent to Bedlam. I will not buy the next book. I'd reather re-read the first three.

I love the Outlander series but this book was a disappointment.  It had no focus...it was all over the lot.  Jamie and Clare were but a small piece of it with much too large a focus on Sir John and his confusing interactions with his renegade step-brother.  I expected and welcomed the story line dealing with Brianna and her family but the convoluted inclusion of her workmate and the kidnapping put the story over the top.  That occurance along with the pairing of Claire and John just made the concluding chapters completely unbelievable (if you can use that word to describe a book about time travel without sounding ridiculous)and very unsatisfying. Diana let us down on this one.

I have loved each of DG's other books in this series. So much so, I cried when I finished "A Breath of Snow & Ashes". I was beside myself the story was so wonderful. All the books have been wonderful. The story lines have been fabulous & so easy to follow & lose myself in. Not this book. The plot is disjointed, less interesting and less riveting. I was disappointed. I kept asking myself, when will it get better. Finally the last quarter of the book things did pick up, but still not to the intensity of DG's previous novels. The only bright point to the lack-luster ending was that it is obvious there will be another book. I pray it will be "verra fierce"!

Like many others, I waited with baited breath for literal years until this book came out. Had my preordered copy in my hands by the day after it was released; living my wildest dream that I have a numbered first edition copy. (and a signed one also that followed a few days later!) In the interim, I read the other 6 three times while waiting... I hate to say it because I love Diana's books... this one was NOT worth the wait. I barely know where to begin without spoiling it for everyone else, but I will say I was knocked for a loop on page one when it started out as, not the beginning of a new book, but a different point of view on the ending to the last book. With the previous six fresh in my mind, this was kind of hard to swallow. Normally, it takes me three days, tops to get thru any one of the Outlander books, and that's with interruptions. This one took ten days, and the honest reason is because I kept putting it down - I couldn't find myself at all absorbed like I normally would be. The entire book is very, very choppy - most Outlander readers are used to hearing 75% of the story as told by Claire - in this book, Claire and Jamie both have less than half the focus on them. Which made it hard to follow because one had to adjust from the way of narration that one is used to. Bouncing back and forth and back and forth... Too much Lord John - he's got his own entire series for pity's sake. It finally started moving and getting really good around page 700 or so... I hit that this morning and didn't stop until I finished it... And when I did, I did the same thing that multiple other reviewers are saying - I went back and skimmed to see if I had missed pages. What happens to Jem? What happens to Roger? Why on earth even bring Buccleigh into the 20th century? To what ends? Jamie and Claire's fate remains uncertain, etc. Too too many loose ends. I understand that a cliffhanger will assure the next book to be a bestseller, but really... With how long it takes Diana to produce a book; it's cruel to her readers and fans that we'll have to wait that long to se what happens. All in all, it was a decent book, but by far NOT her best effort. I agree with other reviewers; it feels rushed, like she was pressed for deadline, etc. And I'm quite disappointed that there wasn't more Jamie and Claire in there... I also didn't care for the touch of the unrealistic with Ned Gowan and Arch Bug... it's the late 1700's.... the only people that lived past 50 years old were the wealthy. There was no valid reason whatsoever that Ned, but especially Arch should have even been still alive. Grr... I suppose it'll be another 3 or 4 times through all 7 of them before I get to find out what happens to everyone. I hope we don't have to wait that long! Bring on the 8th book!

Like a lot of Gabaldon fans, I waited for this latest book like a kid waiting for Christmas. But Santa didn't show up this time. I have felt that Gabaldon's historical writing has been superlative in the other Outlander books. In the past her narrative has read like pure gold. But this book would never be able to stand alone and if this were her first publication it would end up in the discount bin or never published at all. It feels cobbled together and completely disjointed. The characters are not in character, the plot is in disarray and Gabaldon seems to have lost her "voice". It almost feels like someone else wrote the book and she jumped in at the last to try to stitch it together and ramp it up at the end. It reads like it was just throw together and I feel insulted as a reader to have had to struggle through it (twice) and still cannot believe she put her name on this. Very disappointing.

I've been a fan of this series since reading Outlander, the first in the series, and have loved them all.  I never minded the number of pages because reading about the lives of Jamie and Claire was such good entertainment.  A truly classy time-travel romance and adventure.  These two characters were brought to life, a great talent by any author, in all the previous books.  Sadly, this book was a complete let down.  Jamie and Claire were lost in the lives of so many other characters and happenings, and rarely were these tied in to any kind of ongoing storyline.  These two are the central characters, and will always remain so for me.  Very disjointed, almost as if they were written by the author in clumps and then stuck together in one book cover to make a deadline.  I don't care for the Lord John tie in, never did, and too much time was spent with that.  It really wasn't necessary for the cliff-hanger ending as her fans would continue to buy the ongoing saga, regardless.  I gave it two stars only because some of the adventures were about Jamie, Claire, Bree, Roger, etc., and because of the previous great books in this series.  Thank you, Ms. Gabaldon, for your previous books; I'll keep and re-read them all, but this hardcover will be donated to the senior citizen's reading library.  If I do decide to try her next book - in two years probably - it will be from the library as I will not be purchasing it.

Reading these books has become more habit than anything else.  I really have not enjoyed the last few books and this one was no exception.  I sort of feel obliged at this point to see the story to its conclusion so it would be nice if it would finally conclude.

I have read everything Diana Gabaldon has published and I have thoroughly enjoyed all of them up until this one.  This story is disjointed and hard to follow.  It is definately not the authors best work.  It almost seems like there was no editor for the entire book and that the last 200 pages are missing.  This would have been much better had it been split into several separate books; one for each branch of the family, because none of the story lines seemed to go together.  The biggest disappointment was that there was no resolution to any of the main issues.  I feel cheated.  Roger, racing to save his kidnapped son, may or may not be stuck somewhere in the past - we don't know if he survived the passage through the stones or even if he went through them.  Is Jem going to get sucked into the past?  And if he does will he be trapped in stone since in the modern world the passage is inside a tunnel that most likely doesn't exist in the past?  What about William, John and Jaime now that the secret's out? The scene with Arch Bug, Ian and Rachel was left as a mass of confusion. What are William's intentions toward Rachel? Is there going to be a conflict with Ian?  Go back and finish the book Diana.  You owe it to your readers.

First let me say I am a HUGE fan of this series. However, this "book" is not a book. There is no ending, no continuity and obviously no copyeditor. The typos and contradictions are simply too much to bear and the endless wandering through subplots in the company of auxiliary characters is simply infuriating. I am truly disappointed. And just when you think you are being rewarded for loyally slogging through a squillion boring chapters, the story finally gets exciting and promptly ceases to go on. If you venture into this swamp of a manuscript (a `book' is edited and has an ending), prepare yourself for a long and fruitless journey.

Usually I can't beat for Gabaldon's books to end...however, this time, I was desperately longing for an end.  This is the weakest book in the series to date.  There are too many incidental characters, few of whom I feel a great affection for after all these years.  The author refuses to age the characters realistically.  Claire is 60+ and is engaged in scuffles on the high seas.  Parts of the story are totally implausible.  Gabaldon spent so much time incorporating historical events, figures, and details in the story that the main characters suffered tremendously.  The end of the book is rushed.  I was disappointed.

Ohmygosh! What a horrible experience to trudge through the first third of this book! I couldn't take it anymore. Incredibly confusing. I lost track of who is who and quickly began not to care to find out. Nowhere is there clarity. Even the online book summaries and reviews do not help. I can only guess that because this is one of a series, THIS IS NOT THE BOOK TO BEGIN WITH. I am ready to run screaming into the night over this book and very happy its a library book and not owned by me. Narrow escape.

I've read a lot of negative reviews for Diana Gabaldon's latest book and although I agree with some of what others have said, I think we really need to look at the big picture.  Yes, it's a series about Jamie and Claire.  Yes, we want to read about them more than we want to read about Bree and Roger or Lord John or William.  But, Jamie and Claire are not just Jamie and Claire any more.  Bree is part of their family.  And Roger, Jem and Mandy are part of Bree's family.  And Bree is Jamie's daughter.  And William is Jamie's son.  I'll admit that I wasn't that jazzed about having to read ALL those pages upon pages about William, but now that I have finished the book, I think I see what Diana Gabaldon is trying to do:  William made friends with Ian.  He let Ian slide.  As a British officer, that's a no-no.  But, because he did that for Ian, I grew to like William.  I think he's a good kid.  I don't like him as much as I like Ian, but he's okay.  And Diana said a while back that she believed it would take two or three more books to get to the end of her story.  So, I never expected all the loose ends to be tied neatly with a bow.  The series is Jamie and Claire's story.  So, although I don't love this book the way I loved Outlander or Voyager, I'll give it three stars for effort.  And I will stick with it for the next however many books it takes to get to the end.

No wonder it took Gabaldon over three years to write this installment.  I can't believe she spent page after page re-intoducing characters from previous books.  After a while it felt like she was just filling up pages.  The story did not flow well and frankly, some of the scenarios became SSDD (same stuff, different day).  I love that Jamie got back to Claire again, but I'm not sure I'll even bother to read the next one that comes out.

I give three stars because Diana writes beautifully and I honor her previous efforts, but I agree with every negative review, especially about this book having a lot of irrelevant story lines that go nowhere.  I have always hated soap operas and that is what her series has become. I hate being teased and manipulated and again, it feels like this. I tried to read the whole book and enjoy the journey, but hey, I have a full time job and a family and simply didn't have the energy to plow through all the battles and keep track of the numerous plot lines.  I love the characters which is why I stay loyal to the series, but please, let's have a resolution.

I just finished reading the book, and I am so disappointed that we don't know what happens to some of the characters.  Had I known that we need to wait for another book, I would have waited and bought both books at once.  I agree with others that the book was choppy, and that there should have been more of the main characters, not so much of minor ones.  Also, I don't like all the violence in the books.  I read the books for the love of Jaime and Claire.  I don't need to read graphically all the horrible things that happened.  After reading about the woman being burned, I was upset for days.

The first three books of this series are phenomenal. I can only guess that the people that gave this book 5 stars are extremely loyal readers and can't bring themselves to criticize Diana Gabaldon. I found myself skipping through most of the book, and found that I didn't care about the "cliffhanger" at the end. All I have to say is the last book of this series better be good, because since the end of Drums of Autumn, I have been sorely disappointed with the unnecessary storylines and new characters, and the ridiculous amount of detail that doesn't matter.

I am so bummed out by this book.  I did read it to the end but only because I'm a fan of the series and I skipped A LOT of pages just because it was so boring.  I can't even believe that I'm saying that but it was.  I never could get into it and all the William and John Grey stuff was a waste of time.  Take all that extra junk out and the book would be half the size and at least better.  As far as the main characters we love so much?  Well I still love them but it just wasn't the same.  If this wasn't part of the Outlander series I wouldn't have bothered to finish it.

Having read the previous books, I bought this with high hopes of a continuation of the story.  It did continue with about four or five different story lines.  Right now I'm on page 550 and it's like pulling teeth trying to read it.  The previous books only took me about five to seven days to read.  I've been trying to read this one for two months.  I can only stand three or four pages before I fall asleep and I've read six books in between.  I'm very disappointed in the story lines.  If you are a true fan and have to read this book, good luck.

I share the sentiment that An Echo in the Bone does not read like a DG book at all--sloppily written with no regard for the flow of the story. From the point the Jamie suddenly dies, (with no regard for poor Claire's feelings), to the crummy ending leaving the little guy in the tunnel like a cheap comic book trick; there is no hope at all. Please, please, bring back the Jamie and Claire we have grown to love--with all of the fine writing---and great story telling.

This book was a total disappointment.  Very, very little actually happens yet she manages to stretch out about 3 small relevations into a bloated 900 pages.  She could have slashed out half of the book and it still would have been too long and ponderous. I like big books but only if they are entertaining.  This, most assuredly was NOT.  Her last book, A Breath of Snow and Ashes was so good and I was hoping this would be too but my advice is to get it out of the library or wait for her next book as the ending clearly is muddled and leaves the reader hanging.  You could actually skip this book and start with her next and you wouldn't be missing much at all.  My sister and I both bought this book and as she was ahead of me, I would call and ask, "Does it get any better?" and she said,"Basically, you have a lot of battles, Claire patches everybody up, Claire and Jamie have a lot of sex, and I'm going to start skimming now." That about sums it up.  Huge disappointment.

What can I say? I love the outlander series but this one was terrible almost as bad as fiery cross, YAWN ! I was so bored and disappointed, Hated the ending sooooo rushed and unbelievable ! It would compare with the shower scene from Dallas "all a dream" so stupid, come on Di get back to what we want to read about "Jamie & Claire" and stop with with all the dramatic Hollywood shock tactics..

Diana jumped the shark with this one.  Yes, it was a bit slow and disjointed...but the last 1/4 of the book just had too many weird plot twists that were simply unbelievable.  And unresolved at the end!  Not unresolved as in, "be sure you buy my next book", but unresolved as in, "did the editor forget to include a chapter or two?  This storyline just evaporated!"  I was disappointed.
I was very disappointed with this book, and probably wont read any more of hers. The story lines are getting ridiculous and the whole story felt like she is stretching it out to get paid more.

So far I have enjoyed this series, but this one was boring.  I love history but there was too much in this book about characters other than Jamie and Claire.  Too much moving about.  I doubt their moving about as much as in this book.  I feel there will be another novel.  I have serious doubts about purchasing if there is one.

I love the Outlander series that Diana Gabaldon has written and look forward to her next installment.  An Echo in the Bone, I must admit, has been my least favorite of the books in this series.  She did a good job of making Ian Murray a major character and I am so excited to find out what his future holds.  Jamie and Claire have become a little stodgy and there was just too much of Lord John Grey and his intrigues in the book.  One aspect that surprised me was the "artistic license" that Gabaldon took with the historical facts.  I realize this is a work of fiction, but it seemed like she took great care to make it as historically factual as possible so was a little taken aback by the deviation from what really happened.  An example is the return of Simon Fraser to Scotland for burial and his wife, who was childless and waiting in Scotland for her husband's return from his soldiering.  The reality is that she and General Fraser lived in Vermont where their child, Simon Fraser, Jr., was born.  After Simon Fraser was killed at Saratoga, they fled to Canada and the child became a famous explorer and was a big part of the fur trade and exploration of western Canada.  The Fraser River in British Columbia is named for him.  General Fraser was buried onsite after being shot by Timothy Murphy at the urging of General Arnold, which was accurately described by Gabaldon in her book.  I hope all of the threads that unraveled in this book are bound together at some point in her future installment(s).

I've read and enjoyed all of Gabaldon's previous books, including the Lord John series. If I had not, it is doubtful I could have followed EITB at all. As it is, there is far too much material on Lord John and his connections. This should have been the continuation of the FRASER family's story -- not Lord John's. Too many oddly appended characters and too many loose ends hanging at the end with no real story resolution. It just stopped, as though the printer decided the number of pages was sufficient and quit at that point. I really wish I had waited to read it from the library rather than paying for a hardback book. It's an okay read, but certainly not up to Gabaldon's previous standards. Methinks she has too many irons in the fire (graphic novel, other works, update of Outlandish Companion), and just wasn't paying very good attention to the story in this book.

This novel disappointed me. Too much time is spent in the battles in NY State that ultimately do not drive the plot along. It is told from many points of view so can be fragmented. There's not enough time spent with Jamie and Claire. The end of the book is particularly disappointing because it just seems to stop. There's no conlusion to this episode - its almost like one day the editors called the book in and Diana just stopped. There are some interesting tales told and the last 25% of the book is great, but this is a book for someone who already knows and loves this series, not for anyone who is new to it.

It's almost like the author lost interest in Jamie and Claire and has decided to focus on...battles?...or Lord John? I'm not overly sure what exactly the focus is on, but I do know that she's lost sight of her two main characters. I had to go back and reread the ending just to make sure I didn't miss something, unfortunately, I didn't. It was a slow go, slogging through all of the historical mumbledy jumbo to get snitches and pieces of Jamie, Claire and the rest of the family. I've been following (and rereading) the series since the late 90's and can't believe this is what I've been waiting for.

Tedious, boring, and worst of all Gabaldon effectively killed the wonderful romance between Jamie and Claire. I waited so long for this, and the wait was not worth it, not in the slightest. I am so disappointed.

An Echo in the Bone was a huge let down.  I love long books, love to get into the characters, but it seems all this book got into was a couple battles of the war.  I kept waiting, thinking the next chapter would get better.  All of a sudden it ended - like the author had to meet a deadline or something.  So many questions unanswered, so many loose ends.  It didn't make sense.  I was VERY disappointed and not even sure that I'll read a sequel if there ever is one.

I thought there was way too much of the story away from Claire & Jamie & Brianna & Roger and I found myself wanting to skip the sections on Grey and William.  This book didn't hold my interest like the previous books did.

With this book, Ms. Gabaldon insults the intelligence (and tries the patience) of all of us who have followed this series from the beginning.  I have read all of these books, some of them multiple times, and the only reason I am giving this one 2 stars is because it is an improvement over some of the others.  Where is the author who gave us Outlander, and Dragonfly in Amber?  I want her back.  She had a PLOT for her characters.  She gave us storylines that were plausible.  Her writing style elicited emotion.  Her narration style (although always moving around) could be followed, and added interest and suspense to the story rather than distracting from it.  My first thought on completing this book was, "What happened to the editor?".  Then I realized that perhaps this was the best the editor could do with what he/she was given.  Sad sad sad.  I've always thought that the mark of a truly good writer is one who knows not only how to start a story, but also (and most importantly) how to end it.  End it already, Ms. Gabaldon.  I for one am running out of patience.

I have read all the outlander series and was excited to get the latest one in the series. I could tell as I got nearer to the end it was going to have a sequel, but what I found when I got to the end that the author forgot to finish the book. Do not start this one until you have the next one. Oh and review up before you start otherwise you may not get what's happening in the story.

Like other Diana Gabaldon fans, I eager awaited the latest in the OUTLANDER series.  Sadly, this time, I was disappointed.  What can I say?  There's no resolution of any story line.  No feeling of ahhhhhhhh... another GREAT read.  Just disappointment and wondering if it's just time to let Claire and Jamie fade to dust.  What a shame.

I usually read all D. Gabaldon's books twice before reviewing, but I don't think I can read "Echo" again. This book was full of plots that weren't interesting, characters that didn't capture my attention, and letters that were downright boring. Unbelievable that that adjective could ever apply to an Outlander series novel! This read like a Lord John novel to me, and I have never been able to get past the first chapter in those books. What I think the main problem is, as others have mentioned, that the essence of Claire and Jamie have been lost. I love many of the other characters,am looking forward to seeing what happens to Ian, Fergus, Jenny, and especially with Roger. By the way, I'm almost over poor Roger being emasculated by Brianna, isn't it time he can do some things better than her? However the greatest disappointment was the ending, which was obviously thrown together and crammed in. I found much emotion lacking, was aghast that I wasn't more upset regarding things that occurred; (well to me, Claire didn't seem to be either,)and how it was tidied up quickly at the end. I even found myself somewhat thoughtful about a new relationship for Claire beginning. (I'm trying to leave out spoilers.) Let me clarify, Diana Gabaldon is still my favorite writer, and if she never writes another great novel her previous books still stand above all others to me. Yet as much as I love historical novels, I'm not in 5th grade and don't think she needs to go into detail quite as much to convey the storyline. I hope she remembers how to incur the excitement of the adventures of the previous novels, yet most of all to convey the personal interactions between the characters. Because isn't the love between Jamie and Claire really the glue that holds the books together?

If you love the storyline between Jamie and Claire, skip this book. It's very choppy, and there are too many story lines opened at the very end of the book, that end abruptly, leaving you very upset! Shame on mrs. Gabaldon! Hopefully the next book will be like the previous ones.  I am not sure if I am going to find out.

I love all of her books and she is a great writer.  I think maybe she got carried away with so many different themes going in different directions and it was taking too long to finish.  I was reading it on my kindle so I didn't notice that I was at the end and then I just couldn't believe it was the end. She ended the book as though her publisher said he needed it and she gave it to him on the following Monday.  The reader is totally left hanging on several different levels.  It's hard to beleive this was a book by a professional. However, I will be there when the next one comes out and hopefully she will explain how it all fits together.
Almost everything has already been said in other reviews.  I just have to reiterate: are you kidding with that ending?!

As a long time fan of the series I was very disappointed in this edition.  The story line was chaotic at best.  I'm not a prude, but some of the sex was over the line and very out of character.  Would Jamie really send Claire across the ocean during war time so that he could stay and hold his cranky sister's hand when all of her grown children and grandchildren where there with her?  I think not.  I never thought I would get to the point when I said enough of this series, but I'm afraid that in the next book, Bree and Roger and Ian and the Quaker Girl will be having a foursome.  You lost me Ms. Gabaldon.

WARNING: SLIGHT SPOILERS. So incredibly disappointed. I couldn't even make it through this book. I just skipped to the end (Really? Really??? UGH.) to get it over with. Seems like Diana couldn't wait to get it over with too and just dropped this random ending in. It was painful to see how far off-task the original idea had gotten. The series started out strong and good and then fell apart when they left Scotland for America a few books ago, and also when the focus came off Jamie and Claire.

Loved the previous Outlander books.  This reads like a collection of draft scenes not a novel.  Infuriating ending.  Ridiculously slow in some places and ridiculously fast in others.  Bad job all around.

Unfortunately, I began to wonder if I paid for the ebook and didnt recieve all of it, it just ended with no actual closure to the book. Although not the best book in the series it was still okay, the ending is one of the WORST I have ever encountered though and am thoroughly disappointed. I sure I am not mistaken and that Amazon or whomever copied this for ebook didnt leave out a final chapter.

I wish I could time travel two weeks into the past so as to not purchase this book.  I have thouroghly enjoyed all previous novels from the series and was excited to meet up again with characters that feel like close friends.  To my amazement, however, I found myself skimming (rather than reading) page after page -- it was just so boring. And then the end -- pathetic and disappointing.  Rushed and disturbing character behavior that was completely "out of character", and lots of cliff hangers.  Pathetic to make people wait another 4 years for the next novel in order to resolve these storylines. I have never finished one of Diana's books before and felt so disguted that I needed to write a review to vent. Diana, you really wasted my time and have ruined some of the magic of this series.  I still want to know what happens next, however, I do not care as much as I used to.

What a major disappointment this book was! First of all, she didn't end it! I totally agree with the others in that loose ends are unacceptable...I mean, it's like she just walked away from it...yeah..where are the editors?? The Outlander series, until this last book, has been my very favorite books for a long long time....if you're thinking about getting it...don't even bother!

I love so much about Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series - but both the last book and this one have disappointed me.  After reading a "less than wonderful" review, I agree that maybe DG is showing how much history she's found?  And I absolutely LOVE history, don't get me wrong.  But there was so much in this - too much.  This could have been three books, I think.

To be honest, if this had been anyone but DG, I would have only given one star. I thought Fiery Cross was the weakest book in the whole series but no, Echo makes it look like a work of art. I have been following this story and these characters for over 14 years now, I post on Outlander forums and I look forward to meticulously reading the books many many times. Normally all the other books have a story arc, but this one just has no story to speak of for most of the book and then an abrupt end. Come on, Diana, you are the last author that needs such cheap tactics to draw readers. This whole book just drags on and on and on with nothing of importance or consequence happening for almost 900 pages and then rushed through so many important plots in less than 200 pages. I would have loved to see the time devoted to those plot lines since most of the things that happened were so out of character for everyone. There was way too much time devoted to the the Lord John/Percival story line. That belonged in a Lord John novel, it took away from the book and felt too jarring. The excruciating details of Claire's medial treatments were also very repetitive. There were so many continuity errors to the point of distraction. Someone named Gerald Forbes for three books was all of a sudden referred to as Neil Forbes. The book starts with Jamie and John looking over Bree and Willie and then he claims later in the book not to have seen Willie since he was 12? If it had been any other author, I would have given up in frustration. I had to go back and read the first book in the series just so I could forget about this complete disaster of a book. It pains me to give such a bad review to my favorite author but a bad book is a bad book. Normally, whenever a new book is coming out, I look forward to doing a re-read of ALL the books but for this book, I'll just read the last 150ish pages and be caught up without missing anything at all. I hope this book isn't a sign of how the next book will be but my confidence in DG to deliver a satisfying story and ending to this amazing series is lost.

SO MUCH space is devoted to uninteresting minor characters that I found myself skipping big chunks, trying to find to Jamie and Claire.  And instead of seeing historical events vividly through Claire's experiences, as previous books have done, the entire battle of Saratoga comes across as a random collection of facts - dry and dull.  Of course there is the constant barrage of death-defying moments, which frankly has been grating since the third book.  And the multiple cliffhangers at the end aren't just annoying, they're  preposterous.  I feel as though this was written to set up spin-off series for the minor characters, rather than because there was a story to tell.

I was so excited about this book coming out.  I have read and re-read the other books many times each.  But, this one is not good.  It is slow.  Choppy.  Boring.  Why do I care about Lord John and William?  Claire and Jamie are who I want to read about.  I have talked to several other Outlander readers and they feel the same.  What is the point of this book?  Why do I care?  Why should I read any more?  I don't even want to finish it, many have told me.  This is not what I wanted, expected or even want to spend time on. Diana has really let us all down.

I had never heard of the Outlander series, but I read a LOT. I was browsing through Costco's pile of books trying to find something interesting to read on my upcoming vacation.  I picked up An Echo in the Bone (thinking that a book this thick might actually last the majority of my time off!), and as I typically do, opened to a page in the middle of the book to see if the writing was something that grabbed me.  It sucked me right in, and I tossed it into my cart.  I was NOT disappointed!  I have to say that, even as a seventh book in a series (having never read the preceding books), I was never lost, but never bored with over explanation, either, as to what was going on.  I found that this book moved quickly, with beautiful prose, well written and interesting detail, intelligent and wonderfully wrought characters, and a story that kept me wanting to read more.  I have now gone to my local library to check out the first book in the series, and, as I am almost done, and they do not have book two available, am back at Amazon to get next day shipping with Prime...to make sure that I am not left hanging too long before I get my hands on the next book in the series.  I am very glad that I chanced upon An Echo in the Bone.  It made for an exceptional read (and gave me a new-to-me series to devour)!

As much as I loved the first few books in this series, I am starting to hate these last few.  With the constant introduction of new characters, this could go on forever!  I never watched a soap opera in my life, but am now feeling like I have inadvertently stepped into one.  Though I love the main core of characters, I really just want to see some story lines wrapped up in a way we can put them to rest.  People just don't live through SO MANY crazy situations.  I'm just ready to move on.

Very disappointing!  I am a big Jamie & Claire fan and could have caught up on everything in their lives by just reading the last 200 pages.  The first 600+ pages seemed to be just filler - not very interesting or organized - too much detail about war and medicine.  The last 200 pages reminded me of Voyager, which is my favorite.  So I wish there had been more detail in this part of the book instead of just flashing by in a very hurried manner, leaving me wanting to know more.  And I don't mind a cliff hanger, but this was extreme.  The previous books all tied up better at the end, yet left you anxiously waiting for the next book to see what happens.  I will read the next book and hope that it will be the final one that does neatly wrap everything up.  I also hope it is written more in the style of Voyager.  The last two books have been too full of uninteresting details.  And, when you have to wait 3 years for the next one, some of us may not be around for very many more.
I'm disappointed in this one. I've read and reread all the others in the Outlander series; was this even written by the same author? boo

After struggling but enjoying six books, I thought that the final book would be amazing.  How upset and disappointed I was with the ending.  Ms. Gabaldon not only didn't set up a closure but she started several new plots.  Who and what is Ron Cameron?  Did William rejoin the fighting and denouce his title after he found out Jamie was his father?  Did Jamie escape?  Was Claire's marraige to John annulled?  Did Amanda tell her parents where her brother was?  Unanswered questions go on and on.  The only characters that I felt there was any since of closure with was Ian and his Quacker girlfriend.  I felt the need to get my computer out and finish the book.

The previous six books in the Outlander series were good books.  An Echo in the Bone leaves me wondering what happened to Ms. Gabaldon.  This book has too many plots and characters with little background for the new people.  I felt the last third of the book was written in haste to meet a deadline.  I like a good cliff-hanger, but the ending of this book is a slap in the face.  For instance, how did Rob know to look in Mac's office for information about time travelling?  how could Willie tell Jamie was his father when he could only see Jamie in shadow?  did Mac and Uncle Buck time-travel?  will Bree leave Mandy alone?

I put most of my comments on this book on my blog but I closed the book today thoroughly disappointed. I have waited 3+ years for it to appear in print, bought the hardcover almost immediately. I waited until late December to start the book but after reading the 888 (plus or minus - don't hold me to this), I am left with distaste and anger at how shabbily Ms. Gabaldon treated her fans. There were way too many subplots, too much about various skirmishes in the War for Independence, too many pages describing hot, steamy lovemaking that added nothing to the plots. When I started getting to the last 100 pages, I was worried that this would happen (be left hanging) or, worse, that the wrapping up of the subplots would be hastily and poorly done.  No, I was left wondering about way too many characters, some of which didn't need to even BE in the book. If you are an avid fan, wait at least until the trade paperback comes out. Don't spend your hardearned cash on the hardcover.  I am so angry right now!

Wow, I just finished this book this morning, and I can totally see why people are complaining about being left hanging at the end. I love the Outlander series, and typically I can't put these books down once I start reading, but this book was more than a little confusing at times (too many characters, not enough reminding of who everyone is after waiting quite a few years after reading the last book for this one to come out). The end leaves quite a few story lines hanging with no resolution at all, like we're mysteriously missing the next 50 pages of the book. I reached the final page on my Kindle, and thought, "What?? That's IT??" Very disappointing. Maybe the author grew tired of her characters by the end of the 7th book, who knows...but it would have been nice, seeing as this is the end of the series, to have some closure to the storylines at hand. I actually read 2 different books while I was reading this one because I found it so hard to get into. Too bad - I'll miss Claire and Jamie!

I have very much enjoyed all of Diana's Outlander series until Echo. Actually skipped parts of it due to the boring nature of the material. I think most people read Outlander for Jamie and Claire . . . not William, and certainly not John Gray. Some coverage of Bree and hubby make sense, but the 2 main characters are the Two MAIN Characters. Also, trying to build 3 or 4 books into one precludes any hope of having a flow in the reading experience.  Hoping that Diana will not repeat the Echo format. Terrible!!

I have read all the previous books and loved them. I pre-ordered this book when it was first available.  I am only at the beginning of the book, but I thought I'd look at the reviews to see if anyone else disliked it as much as I have. Not surprised to find I'm not alone. It looks like I will skim through the first 600 pages and just read the last 200. It is so boring, I can't read past a chapter or two without my mind wandering. I will not be buying the next installment, but get it at the library instead.

I've loved the other Outlander books.  This one is incredibly boring!  I can't remember the last time I've gotten stuck in a book and didn't care whether I ever finished it.  There are a very few scenes that are interesting with the main characters but the long historical and political expostulations detract from the story.  What a disappointment!!!!!  I won't be reading any more of these books and that's saying a lot as I have eagerly read each one through the years.

There were several sections that I felt I could have skimmed over mostly the parts with Lord John and William. There were too many cliffhangers throughout the whole book but most of them were unresolved. I'd say the last 150 pages got more interesting which left me wanting more but the ending was too rushed. It was like the author got tired. I guess I'll have to wait for the next book. I'll still a fan of the series overall but this one leaves you just hanging.

I had really enjoyed starting this series and told others about how interesting it was. The  the last book "took the cake." The book, "An Echo In The Bone" was much larger in size and still was just as thick. At the end of this book there was still no conclusion. Will there ever be one?  I cautious you starting this series because there doesn't seem to end, even after 7 books, or how many more books will we have to buy before it does end?

I have been a book-a-holic since I can remember...  I started reading Diana Gabaldon with her first book in this series...and I have loved each and every book that followed...this one included.  Diana is able to "write me a movie" so that not only do I read the words...I can visualize what happens....to me that is the mark of an outstanding author...  I will definitely purchase her next book...and look forward to it eagerly!!

I was so confused at the end of this book - that I went to the bookstore to see if mine was missing pages.  What a way to set up for the next book - cliffhangers are one thing - but it felt like leaving a scene in the middle of a monologue. Those of us that are devoted fans would have bought the next book - it didn't have to leave everything just hanging.

Ugh.  Ugh, ugh, ugh.  I am so disappointed in this book.  There was entirely too much time spent on Lord John and William.  They should have been incidental characters to the main story about the MAIN CHARACTERS of the series, but instead the book feels mostly about them.  If I weren't so disgusted by this book, I would actually go back and count the number of pages spent on Lord John and/or William, just as an illustration of how poorly divided it was.  I can't decide if I want there to be another book in the series.  I would undoubtedly read it, but would I feel--as I do now--that I had wasted my time?

I love this series, but I don't need to read about how Jamie's hair glows in the firelight, or about his musky smell, or about Clare's crazy hair.  After reading all the books to date, I could describe every nook and cranny myself.  In any case, a good - long read, albeit a bit scattered.  I hope there's at least one more to tie up the loose ends.

I am an avid reader and as such, I have devoured all the books preceeding Echo in the Bone fervently.  This one, however... I have broken my own Cardinal rule by actually skipping pages.  Pages and pages and pages of boring letters that read as, (and clearly I am making this up with sarcasm): "Dearest Papa, upon entering the area subsequently known prior to the engagement of the particulars, to be exact and unreknown from hence, and whither tis right or wrong in appraisal, that such comely woman would think me abiding, and such, therefore I buggered her quaintly and rogered her sister accordingly...."  Did people write letters like this?  Do I need to scour the pages to decipher the text into some semblence of modern language?  Really??  I am appalled to admit that this book is BORING.  I've completely skipped over the dreadful letters and most of the William-goes-walkabout garbage to read only the parts which have my interest - those of Claire and Jamie.  I have not yet completed this book, (I am only halfway but am at this point ready to start something new), however after reading the reviews here I am not certain I want to finish it.  No ending?  That just seems a perverted waste of time and effort, to write a book some 1,000+ pages in length, adhering to a story line which has captivated many fans, only to provide no clear ending for the tale.  I can only assume that closure will come in 3-4 years when the next book is written.  Is Diana Gabaldon destined to become the next Melanie Rawn:  leave the fans hanging over a cliff with no end in sight?  Holy bejeeez, I hope not!  As I've read all the books (except the John Grey stuff and, quite frankly, after reading his parts in this book I'm not inclined to try those) back-to-back (a friend lent me her collection) I cannot fathom life without Jamie Fraser as he has been with me these last 7 months; however, I would hope the series does not truly let down with a poorly planned conclusion.  So far, half the book could be scrapped and it wouldn't suffer.

I just finished this book, and since I enjoy all of the characters, Lord John and William as well, I really enjoyed the read.  I really like how the author has developed the story by transitioning toward the next generation.  While I love Claire and Jamie, I enjoy their children just as well.  I was expecting more with Brianna and Roger because of how the last book ended, and so was a little disappointed with both the limited exposure they got in this book as well as the major loose ends in their storyline.
