However, I loved how William's storyline was built in this book - I had always wondered if Diana would get to him at all or if he'd play more of a role at some point - so I forgive the neglect on the Brianna/Roger end of things.  The historical battle scenes at times were a little tedious, but I didn't think they were any more so than the battle of the regulation.  She hasn't surpassed Culloden yet but I'm OK with that.  I thought the meetings with historical characters were a little contrived at times, but no more than meeting King Louis, so as a device it worked as well as it has in her other books.  What was really disconcerting about this book was simply the number of loose ends and the way that they dangled.  This was the first of her books where I was stunned when and where the various storylines ended - very little closure at all on any of them!  Unlike the delightfully evil way Diana ended the last book with such a tantalizing clue, there are no clues at the end of this book as to where things might go, so I'm not even sure what I'm looking forward to other than resolution.  I would have appreciated a few more hints.  My only hope is that the storylines got cut short due to time constraints and so Diana already has them mostly figured out and the next book will be out more quickly!!

Every book in this series is at least excellent. My single complaint is the overwhelming amount of vomit. Somebody barfs in these books every thirty pages or so. If you can live with that then you owe it to yourself to read all the uotlander books

I was so looking forward to this new release but must say I was quite disappointed.  It was chopie and hard to follow but I did finish it.  Really didn't keep me wanting more but thought that it might get better the more I read..but it didn't.  So sorry Diana but this really was a disappoint.

Ok, so maybe I can think of something to say. I was very disappointed with this book! I became an outlander addict almost 10 years ago! This book was definitely not on par with the other books! The first half of the book could have been shorted to a few chapters and she could then have added an ending instead. DG rambles on in the first 200 pages, totally unnecessary! It had nothing to do with the plot. Reading those pages was almost like watching paint dry! In all fairness, about 200-300 pages into the book it FINAL picked up and became a page turner. The problem is it had no ending it just cut off entirely with no resolution! She began ANOTHER plot in the last few chapters of the book and then left EVERYTHING unresolved! It takes her about 3 years to write these books, so that means the readers have a 3 year wait to find out what happens. It makes me want to throw my hands in the air and scream. If you are thinking of reading this book, I would follow the advice of the other readers and wait until she completes the series before reading any more of them!
A disappointment compared to the others in the series, especially the prior book, A Breath of Snow and Ashes, which was probably the best one of the lot.

While I agree with most of the reviews, i.e., choppiness, slow, unsatisfying ending, etc, the main problem I had was the fact that it had been so long since I had read the previous books. I discovered Diana's books later than most and I had the fortune of reading 5 of them, one right after another (I don't remember much else from that summer!)I can't tell you how devastated I was when I found out that book 6 wasn't close to being finished. With that said, it had been quite a while since I read the last one. Wouldn't it have been wonderful if, when she mentions a character from the past, she could footnote it and then have a "cheat sheet" in the back to refresh our memories? This would have been especially helpful when discussing the Percy character - for the life of me, I cannot remember his significance!Or William's real parentage for that matter.

i have followed the adventures of jamie and claire from the start. i loved claire so much that i named my daughter clare. this book was slow at times painful but i liked it very much.  i loved to see jamie and claire as the old married couple who still have the flame and passion for each other.  i enjoyed getting to know lod john and willie. and i was glad to have a lot of the story devoted to ian.  i liked hearing about brianna and roger but the guest who shows up at their house i didnt care.  i didnt find it believable about what claire and lord john do.  and im done but the ending wasnt really an ending. and ill keep reading the series but its painful to be cheated that way. it wasnt fair to leave us all hanging.

Let me first say, I love Diana Gabaldon.  I discovered her a few years back and have been a loyal follower every since.  I would recommended, mainly b/c if you've gotten this far in the series you got to keep going.  I did enjoy her book, but like others, I found that the last 100-150 pages were disjointed and the ending wasn't really an ending.  I felt like she should have stopped it ***spoiler*** when Claire was notified of Jaime's death and Jem went missing.  These would have been good stopping points.  But to continue on to end the book with Ian?  That just didn't make sense!  I am hoping that she will clear things up with her next (final?) book, by filling in the gaps that she left at the end of this one.

First off, let me say that I'm a HUGE fan of Diana Gabaldon and always (hopefully) will be. I've read and re-read the Outlander novels many times. Normally when one of her books comes out I'm on the waiting list for it to be shipped and it's read in about 3-4 days. That being said, I'm embarrassed to admit that I haven't even finished "Echo" yet. I can't get through it. It doesn't flow and the everything is very disjointed in the story-line. I would have to agree with all the comments I've read so far in that it lacks spark and fluidity. I am over half-way through the book,but it's taken me a couple of months. I plan to finish it and will buy her next novel, but I really hoping it's better than this one.

I have looked forward to reading every book in the Outlander series.  This one was a disappointment.  It dragged in several parts.  It was one of the worst non-endings to a book I ever read.  Gabaldon left us hanging with regards to Jem, Mac, Bob Cameron, the Frasers' reunion, Willie, the British evacuation from Philadelphia was  abrupt, no lead-in to that story, no resolution to Lord John's revelation to Jaime.  All this after almost a thousand pages. What was going on here?  I hope the next book isn't too many years in coming and that it is better put together and edited than this one.  And let's not pull a Jean Auel and go on and on describing herbs and other medicinals. Just stick to the story.

This book drove me crazy for the first half, jumping around from one character to another. The part about Lord John and William was downright BORING. About half way in I quit reading for about 2 weeks, then finally picked it up again. From that point on it started to get much better. I thoroughly enjoyed the retreat fron Ticonderoga, and the history with the battle of Saratoga was excellent. I was finally vested in the story. But as I got to 90% (read it on my Kindle), I knew there was no way she was going to tie up loose ends. When the book ended, I felt betrayed. Now, it will probably be three years before the next one comes out. Way too many cliffhangers!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I have to agree with many of the reviews of Echo in the Bone.  I was also a huge fan of the Outlander series until this book.  The first six books of the series were some of the best reading that I've ever enjoyed.  *SPOILERS*  This book, however, was somewhat slow and confusing with so many characters, subplots, and vague references to the Lord John series (which I have not yet read).  The book was choppy, inconsistent and fragmented.  The ending (if you can call it that) was blatantly only a setup for another book which appears not to even have been begun, yet.  That was VERY disappointing.  I'm quite certain that if it takes five years to be written and published, I won't be all that interested.  The relations between Claire and Lord John were displeasing and certainly didn't add to the borderless and ageless romance of the series.  Quite a letdown there.  I agree with other readers that if Ms. Gabaldon is tired of writing about Jamie and Claire, she needs to wrap up their story and move on to another series.

I've read all of the Outlander series and feel as if I've invested enough time and money in these characters to deserve more than a disjointed, dissatisfying "little Nell tied to the railroad track" type cliff hanger ending for everyone of the main characters. Each of the other books in the series tied up loose ends with the appropriate tease of the future.  They made made me feel satisfied but want to keep reading.  This one just annoyed me, almost to the point that I wanted to throw up my hands and say, "enough already."  I assume Gabaldon will eventually give these characters some kind of closure; maybe I'll overcome my annoyance by then enough to care.

I am shocked and sadden at an Echo in the Bone.  I have read the entire Outlander series and have loved every minute of it.  This book however changed that.  This book was long and drawn out.  There were a lot of story lines to follow, and the ending was horrible.  It was as if Diana Gabaldon just decided that she had written enough and stopped.  All of the story lines are in the middle of something exciting, and it just ends.  I am so disappointed that I have spent the past few months reading through all of her books to be left hanging without any answers.  If I had the choice to do it again, I would not read the Echo in the Bone.

I am very old and I have read thousands of books- fiction, non-fiction, biographical, historical, libraries-full. I have read all the DG Outlander books and I love the Jaime and Claire story, but this is awful!!! I believe I have walked away from only 2 books in my entire life without finishing them and this will be the third. DG - how could you?

As I reached the end of this book, being an avid reader of this series, I found myself wondering if the publishers got a hold of Diana's notes instead of the actual book. Without going into too much detail, Claire did not act "in character" toward the end at all, nor was I convinced of her grief. The end was just far too choppy, and as others have said, there were continuity issues all through the book which probably bothers me more than anything else. I would think authors would read the ending of a previous book to make sure they are picking up at the right spot. It had been years since I read Breathe and I knew right away that Echo was starting differently than Breathe had ended. I will read the next one for sure and I sincerely hope it's better. I recently started reading them all again from the beginning and am finding myself almost dreading getting to Echo because it was so disappointing the first time through.

Argh!!  This book is SOO disappointing!  I loved this series until I spent a week and a half of my life trudging through pages and pages of Revolutionary war battles full of mind-numbing details, to finally get to the last 10% of the book where all the action FINALLY starts happening--just to have everything left in the air. Will I read the next book?  Probably.  I'm just so disappointed in this one!  Please, next time, give us more of the main core of characters that we have come to love!  And some time travel would be nice, too . . .  This book a serious waste of paper--2.7 pounds of it to be exact.

First, I love this series.  I've read them all three times.  This one, however, is the least favorite.  Why?  Way too much Lord John Grey who is, IMHO, boring. This is Jamie and Claire's book.  Leave John Grey in his own books - mixing his adventures with Jamie and Claire doesn't do them any favors and makes this book way too complex.  There are too many characters here with linkages and overlaps that are beyond belief.  (yes, I know time travel is a bit of a stretch but Gabaldon makes it believable).  Brianna and Roger suffer neglect in this story too.  It's just too complicated.  The ending is no ending but a major frustration.  Since it takes about three years for Gabaldon to write one of these tomes that means...3 years of hanging about waiting to see what's next.  Not fair to her legions of faithful readers.  Who edited this???  Maybe someone else next time??

As others have already written, there are too many loose ends.  I'm really disappointed that DG is going to make us wait probably another 3 years for the ending.  I have to admit I love reading about Claire and Jamie.  Even though nothing was really happening, it was fun to just read about their day to day life together.  I'm only putting in my 2 cents to say, "Yes, I agree with others."  Hopefully she will listen to her fans and NEVER do that again.  Now that she has done that, I worry she will do something else equally unexpected (and unwanted) in the next book.

I've am an avid fan of the "Outlander" Series, I have the complete set (except this last tome) in audio format as well as in written media.  I love the audiobooks and when I found out the audio version would not be released until November, I downloaded "An Echo in the Bone" to my Kindle.  I was disappointed and saddened.  I love the relationship between Jamie & Claire and I felt their voices lacking in this book, AND repetitve:  ocean voyages, pirates, in other words, the same old tune on a new background.  I also thought too many pages were dedicated to John Gray.  William's escapades were a bit tedious until the last portion of the book and then...egad, the reader is left out there with so many threads to grasp at the end, it is frustrating. I was glad to learn more of Bree's & Roger's life, especially the kiddies, yet their story as well as many of the others in this book are disjointed and hop all around.  I did enjoy the letter reading portions with Roger & Bree.  I did give the book three stars (which = okay) because the book is only okay and pales to the forerunners of this series.  Yet, I would still read it again, in fact I need to because I skipped over many of the FOG pages, starring William. Oh well.

The ending was rushed and completely shortchanged compared to the extensive fleshing out of every other scene in the book. It needed at least another 200 pages to do justice to some very significant plot developments. We saw so little of these events that they didn't ring true, in my opinion. I just felt completely cheated at the end. I'm a huge fan of the Outlander series and have rated all the other books 5 stars, but this left a lot to be desired. Especially a massive cliffhanger that was almost unforgivable to not resolve!

I have loved all of the previous books involving Jaime and Claire and was so disappointed in this book.  When I was finished, I literally threw the book across the floor and wrote her publisher telling them that the ending left so many things unanswered and I feel it was irresponsible of Diana Gabaldon.  I was so upset that this author that I have enjoyed and recommended to so many has manipulated her fans by keeping so many story lines open in the end, trying to force you to buy the next book.

First,  I think Diana Gabaldon is the best author I have ever read.  BUT she set the bar too high for herself!!!  First,  I just don't care for the "Lord John" story lines,  I am sure I am not alone in that I really want to read about Claire and Jamie, and their kids!  Yes, William is Jamies child, but not Claires, so the whole war storyline about John and William I found myself skimming over and wanting to get back to Claire and Jamie.  The ending was the clincher,  I felt like someone yanked the book out of my hands in the middle of a sentence.  There is leaving a reader wanting more and then there is leaving the reader thinking they missed half the book!!  Totally UNacceptable, giving that how fast she writes books, means I will be on social security before I get to know the next thing that happens.  Nora Roberts can do this, she writes and puts out 2-4 books a year.  Diana Gabaldon, Ms.-  book- every- 4-5 -years- can -NOT!  Kind of a disappointment, really.

Not sure what all the fuss has been about with other reviewers.  This story is Ms. Gabaldon's to tell and if some of the twists and turns don't match readers expectations - remember it is a story and Claire anf Jamie are characters.  I loved the historical detail, the authentic language, and the brilliant prose.  Thank you to the author for continuing to share the remarkable gift of her imagination and writing genius with us!

I have been salivating at the thought of Echo In The Bone coming out, but now I am so confused. I have all her other books and listened to them on cd when travelling, but I am having to reread each chapter or go back a few to remember what happened to William or Lord John. If you haven't read the Lord John series, you might be confused who Minnie and Hal are. And then there are all these new characters! I had to write everyone down to keep them straight. I'm kind of sad, because I wanted it to be more like her other books. I hope the next one will make up for this. And I'm a die hard Diana fan! =(

I preordered the next book "Written in My Own Heart's Blood" on May 2013 thinking that it was going to be released this December.  Now I see it's rescheduled for release in June 2014!  That's 13 months after I preordered it.  Today I've canceled that order and am not sure that I will continue to read these books.  The first couple of the Outlander books were outstanding and I will read them again.  Is Ms. Gabaldon taking advice from the "Game of Thrones" author George R.R. Martin who is infamous for the long delays between his books?  Very disappointed.

I gave this book 3 stars so maybe my review would be read.  It deserves one star.  Read the one star reviews...they say it all and say it as it is.  It's time to end this series or go back to the drawing board.  Too long, a bit boring, and the ending is ridiculous.  Way too may plot lines.  I get annoyed with authors who write incredibly long books just to keep up the image.  Is it money that writes the books?  Not sure I can stomach reading another.

If you love these audio books like I do, you know that Geraldine James makes them practically Nirvana. This book has a different narrator all together, just not the same. So, be warned, if you adore Geraldine James, you may want to borrow before you buy, just in case it's not your cup of tea.

This book I fear, is just the proloug of book 7 of Ms. Gabaldon's Outlander series.  She only set up all the what going happens and was long winded as well.  Rather mean of you Ms. Gabladon; you took a big risk of loosing many fans.  I think I'll go re-read all of Robert B. Parker's Spenser novels in his memory.  He was never was mean to his fans and neither was Spenser.

I would have to agree with other reviewers on this one.  I am a big Outlander fan, having read or reread nearly all the books, listened to the audio books, and viewed the companions such as Outlandish Companion and the graphic novel.  I even read the Lord John books (which were entirely uninteresting to me).  That being said, the timeline is very choppy (the story skips between too many storylines, and people who the reader does not care about).  I don't mind some suspense, but to be left hanging while the author takes 150 pages to describe the flora and fauna is, frankly, exasperating.  I found myself skimming over entire sections much more in this book.  It is true that all of the books at times did go on a bit in terms of descriptions and historical background, but because the storyline was so solid, it was still pleasing to the reader.  In ECHO, the payoff for all of that extra detail is simply not there.  Also, there are numerous errors and inconsistencies.  I can't believe how absolutely ridiculous the main characters behave - completely out of their character - or at least the character they had been in the previous books.  Claire seems so weak.  It was shocking how much she fainted and cried in this book.  I did enjoy the current day storyline with Roger and Bree reading the letters from Claire, even though I have always found Bree's character to be overly defensive and frustrating, but found myself skipping forward to them to get a payoff and then going back to play a little catch-up.  The segments on Lord John and William were too long and, honestly, did not add the substance of the story in my opinion.  I am very disappointed in this book.  *spoiler* The ending leaves readers with little closure in a story you know will not be continued for possibly years, which is nearly unethical.  We are left with Jem missing, Roger having plunged through the stones but no idea where he landed, Bree in confrontation with a kidnapper in search of the gold, William on a violent spree after learning of his parentage, Jamie being hunted by soldiers, and no idea how the confrontation with Arch Bug ended.  Sigh.  That is a little excessive.

I bought all 7 of the "Outlander" series books at the same time and read them in order. I loved all of them. "The Fiery Cross" being my least favorite until "Echo". When the 6 previous books ended, you had a sense of completion in the event Ms. Gabaldon chose not to write another book. I'll not go into the outline of the series because other commentators have done an excellent job of doing so. I did realize Ms. Gabaldon in "Echo" was writing a transition book because Jamie and Claire are getting old and I assume the "series" will eventually go on without them. Good business sense. But I must say when I got to the end of "Echo", I thought at first that I had missed reading some chapters but I did not. Being terribly aggravated, I thought the printers left some chapters out of this batch of books including the last 2 or 3 because certainly this is not the end!! Finally, I went on line and found I wasn't the only one that felt this way. BIG LAUGH ON ME. Enough of that disappointment. What was Ms. Gabaldon thinking; Lord John and Claire having sex???? GROSS; Jamie bringing Jenny back to America with him. Ugh!! I've had enough of her. But after saying all of this; here I am anxiously awaiting the next book! I recommend all the "Outlander" books. The series is about the life, love, and adventures of Jamie and Claire Fraser who came together during a time travel episode. After the 2nd or 3rd chapter in the first book, "Outlander", Jamie and Claire "hit the ground running" and never stop!! Thank you Ms. Gabaldon.-----'Revisit'---- Wish me luck. MS. Galbadon will release the next book in the series, "Written In My Heart's Own Blood", early in 2013. I'm going to start reading the first 7 again. A herculean task but well worth it!! Don't miss out on this series. The release of the next book has been pushed back until late 2013, DISAPPOINTMENT for me!!

O.K. I don't know where to begin.... Well, I suppose I should start with the beginning. I really loved the whole "Mr. and Mrs. Bug incident". Yes it was so sad, but it did add a "looking over your shoulder" kind of feeling to the story and threaded throughout the novel as well. I will always love Jamie and Clare's love scenes. I don't care how old they are!!!! I love reading about Jem! I love that kid! I really enjoyed reading about Ian and his new love (not going to mention her name). Wished the couple would have become a little more romantic though. I am so glad to feel some closure between he and Emily. Wow...the son (swiftest of lizards)! I would like to see Ian in his son's life in the future! I liked the historical fiction, but I feel it was overdone. It should be the storyline and plot taking center stage and the historical story behind it, rather than the other way around. I felt the author was so very excited to tell the historical elements of the story that the story of Jamie and Clare and their family somehow became overshadowed by history. I love love love the Outlander Series. It will always and forever be my first love when it comes to historical romance. However, I felt a little cheated. I like that we were able to get to know William, Jamie's son a little better, however I felt like I wanted to get to know him and connect with him more emotionally, like getting into his skin. I feel I only met him outwardly! I am not upset over what happened with John and Clare. I feel though that the reader was not given enough time to digest it. It was all wham bam thank you ma'am sort of thing. If this is going to be written into the novel, then I feel that the author should have allowed some sort of "affection" to be unfolded between John and Clare. Obviously not woman attraction or affection on John's part, but some sort of connection so that we could have eased into what transpired between them. It was SO unexpected that it didn't settle right. I do like John's character a lot. He is a gentleman and he is an attractive man. In previous novels, he and Clare do enjoy one another's company and brief conversations like in the 3rd and 4th novels. She nurses him back to health at one point or maybe twice. So I don't think it was completely far fetched that it happened. Plus they were both grieving. I just felt it wasn't as believable as it could have been. Jamie was only missing for only a couple of chapters it seems and therefore it wasn't enough time for the reader to accept what happens with John and Clare. That situation really had potential, but it felt short. In A Breath of Snow and Ashes, Jamie did write a letter to John...more like he left him his will. It was only logical for John to assume caretaker of Clare for his BFF! I mean he already raised Jamie Fraser's son! Why not care for his widow too! Anyway, I felt that the scenes with the most meat were rushed and cut too short. These were the scenes we had waited for all this time! I wish we could have extended on the whole Jamie and son scene at the end of the novel. It was soooo rushed and left me...words fail me. I'm not sure about the whole William Buckliegh Mackenzie time traveler extraordinaire thing! All I can say is that I am expecting soooo much more from novel number 8!!! I want answers! Let's face it! We all love a happy ending and reunion! That's why we loved Outlander and let's not forget Voyager's Jamie and Clare's reunion! Ahhh! What a scene! I want to see Willie getting to know Jamie and his roots. I want to see Jenny and Clare as friends. Let's find Jem! I don't want novel number 8 to be all history and in the end we find Jem and just throw and hasty happy scene together. Please take us on an adventure and bring back the love and romance full force as well! P.S. I'm glad Tom Christi is... (I will not say, but I like that)He was a good guy and deserved a better fate. That's all I can think of for now.

Can someone please explain the beginning of the book to me?  The dead body in the water that they take down? Brianna is in this scene, but it's in the past and I just can't remember how this ties into the previous book and it doesn't really seem to tie into this book.

This author just repeats the same scenarios over and over again.  How many times can someone be kidnapped? How many people can possibly fall in love with Jamie (men and women)?  The repetition is not only from book to book, it is in the same book.

I agree with some of this review. The most disturbing and disappointing to me besides the repetiive rapes, I mean father, mother, AND daughter are raped! Come on. Also, Claire's reaction to Jamie's supposed death was quite anticlimactic and much less emotional than I wanted it to be.I mean she was in deeper depression when the lady was allergic to Penicillin (which she brews in bowls, come on!!!) than she was to possibly losing Jamie forever. She bounced back pretty quickly as well being that Jamie is supposedly the love of her life. Marries Lord John (yet again to protect her from a spying charge and hanging) and actually has sex with him not days after Jamie is assumed dead. When he returns too, she is underwhelmed I thought and his response to LJG's carnal knowledge of his wife is quite ridiculous, taking it in stride and all that. It just didn't ring true when u consider his other reactions toward Claire. These books make me wonder if there are two different writers because the styles vary so much. And for the research, you can bet your sweep bippy, she's not doing it on her own. She probably has an army of aides behind her. That's it. Love her descriptive abilities but when you look at it as a whole, her writing and plot lines are not that impressive and often repetitive. BTW, I am a fan but I don't worship her like a lot of people seem to do.

I have rarely read such an incomplete book! It leaves most of the "histories" ongoing. I like the author's style and her attention to details, but I hope she doesn't repeat the lack of closure in her next book.

As many others have said...I love The Outlander series and have given each of them 4 or 5 stars.  I am struggling to give this one 3 stars.  As a matter of fact, I love Diana's writing so much that I have the entire series of autographed, first edition, first printing copies.  I tried to read this book when it first came out and got so bored and lost, I just skimmed through it to try to get to the end.  However, for several months now, I have started the entire series over again starting with the first book..The Outlander and continuing on through each of the other books all of which I love.  I decided that now that every book was fresh in my mind, maybe I could connect with this last book...An Echo in the Bone. No such luck!  I am still bored and confused and having a terrible time getting through it.  I am back to skimming chapters especially the Lord John ones because I can't figure out half the stuff going on with him. I can even put the book down after a few pages to unload the dishwasher, dust, etc.  With the other books...I would think "does my family really need dinner tonight or should I just keep reading?"  With all that said, I am anxiously awaiting the next book and will preorder it when it is available.  Hopefully, this next one will be more in line and just as exciting and fascinating as the first novels.

Too many loose ends. Too many situations that are uncharacteristic or over-used.  I am, again, greatly looking forward to the next book as this volume proved to be of little value.  If the next book is of the same quality as this one, there could be a revolt!

I guess I am one of the lucky ones.  I did not stumble on to Diana Gabaldon until August 2010.  That is when I received this wonderful thing called Kindle!  I read alot as a child, but never read much after grade and Jr high school.  I am not a fan of the "Romance" writting.  I am a 63 year old lady who worked all my youth and did not have time to read.  When I came across the Outlander books I had not read anything since early Koonze....15 or so years ago.  The Outlander books have not only taught me history I never knew...sorry....typing on this little key pad!....but, also have given me so much joy as well.  Like others I am so invested in these people....they fell like friends and family.  I am so glad I did not come across DG until later so I did not have to wait so long for each book...not sure I could have taken it.  Not so sure why all the not so flattering reviews though...  DG thank you for getting a not so young person interested in reading again.  It has become one of the biggest joys of my life now!  If some one can tell me of another writer like DG's style...I would love that.  I am new at all this tech stuff, but am trying my hand at it.  My god how do all of you write such long reviews?  My fingures are numb...

I, like so many readers and reviewers, waited long years for this book. Overall I liked it very much. I live in upstate New York and I will never think of the historic battle sites in quite the same way. To cut to the chase here, I agree with so many others regarding the end of the book.  While suspense is nice and keeps us readers coming back and waiting for the next book, it did seem like Diana was tired and just tried to get the book done...I say done versus finished. Many of the scenarios at the end of the book seem like throw-ins  for some sort of needless excitement. There are other concerns but so as not to ruin someone's read... I liked the story very much as I feel like I know these characters but Diana did not do a good job with the last 100 pages or so. As disappointing as that is, waiting 4 years, perhaps, for the next book is even more disappointing. I am going to be outlining the story line and questions in the back of my book so that when the next one comes out I will have a quick review ready. That is assuming in 4 years that I remember that I have done that!!!

I love this writer's series of Outlander. HOWEVER, she consistently ENDS her novels with several cliffhangers, and then it's 2 years for the next novel. By then you've forgotten most of the last book. VERY UNFAIR! FINISH the novel's cliffhangers. SPOILER ALERT: Leaving Jem in the train in the tunnel and Jamie with John Grey admitting he'd slept with Clare is HORRIBLE, Author. You could AT LEAST finish the story as most authors do, and then set the main characters up for say, return to Scotland, or to North Carolina? But ENDING a BOOK with several unresolved MAJOR issues, in the MIDDLE of them actually, is rotten! This is NOT TV...I don't read a novel just to wait another year or longer to get the resolution!! I'm really tired of this Diana Gabaldon. You write well, but I have to wait SO long for the end to the cliff hangers that it's really hard to keep interest alive. THIS IS NOT TV where you wait 6  months for the resolution....if you want to do that, GO WRITE FOR TV! Doing what you do with these novel endings on cliffhangers is a CHEAP TRICK on your readers.

I loved all the other books in the Outlander series but I find I am growing bored of the same things happening to the characters. How many times can they get ambushed, separated and mortally wounded???

The other two are Lindsey Davis and Deborah Harkness.  All three write characters that get under your skin and become part of you.  And that's good, because you want them to stay.  Brilliant, luminous characters with nuance, shading, depth and complexity.  And they all three take you to different times and places effortlessly, as if you had stepped through a looking-glass.  Anything in Diana Gabaldon's "Outlander" series is utterly engrossing and enchanting.  I feel like I have learned more than in some of my college coursework from her books, from the study of herbs, European and early American history, psychology, and early medicine to  a smattering of Gaelic.  All absorbed as a child learns, exploring an engrossing world and soaking up knowledge about it like a sponge.  Best of all, in Gabaldon's books, you smell the air, feel the temperature, see your breath, hear the crackle of leaves or the sounds of animals and humans.  You _are_ there, a participant in every event, from the most minor to the most important.

I have been reading the "Outlander" series from the very start. This book, as much as I always enjoy the characters and the connection of story line and time line. I was disappointed  with the ending. ONLY because it was not an ending it was a cliff hanger for the next BOOK. (When that will be available only the author & publisher know) All other books seemed to stand on their own. I will read the next book, but I do hope I will not be flapping in the wind waiting for the next book to put pieces together. It's ok to leave some questions unanswered,but not only unanswered, but bringing in characters that came into the story and where never followed through on, or hopefully  will be in the next novel.  How many times can people go through the portals and still stay in one piece. I think it's getting a bit out of hand, and is messing with the original story line. (that is a personal opinion)  When the series first started there was 2 time jumps in 4 books. Now it's line a swinging door. I'm finding that annoying. (also personal opinion) I know it's fiction, but ..............

After reading all the negative reviews on this book, I almost didn't purchase it ... but I just couldn't bring myself to NOT know the next part of the story. So, I dove into it, fully expecting to just muddle through it (kinda like Fiery Cross). I'm writing this review, though, to let people know that it's not as bad as the reviews make it sound. It does have multiple story-lines going on at the same time, but each story is unique in itself (and I guess, some might find the John Grey politics or the Revoluntionary War battle strategy not as interesting as Claire and Jamie's romance), but I found that the story moved along and that there was plenty of Claire, Jamie and Ian to keep me intrigued in the story. The thing I love about Gibaldon's books is that I rarely know what's going to happen next, and for sure, by the end of this book, I really didn't know what was going to happen next. If you've come this far, dig in. It may not be your favorite part of the saga, but it is part of the saga and well worth your time.
One of her best books yet...and the ending was a bit of a cliffhanger that makes you anxious for the next book.  Excellent read!

As a new Gabaldon fan (thanks to the Starz series) I must say I didn't like this book. My three stars rating is overly generous. If book eight turns into a repeat of this book I'm done buying Gabaldon's books. Way too much filler and not enough Jamie & Claire time in this book. It's like Gabaldon has reached an impasse and has little more she can write about Jamie & Claire and so filled this book with historical events. The lengthy emphasis on other characters left me frustrated. None of Gabaldon's books are as good as Outlander her first novel. I have really liked (Voyager and Drums of Autumn) and some were of lesser quality (Dragonfly in Amber and Fiery Cross) but none were as boring as this book. Gabaldon will have to redeem herself with her eighth book or we will be parting ways.

I cried when I read the final page of "A Breath of Snow & Ashes".  My time traveling experience was over and I had lost my connection with the beloved characters so skillfully created by Diana Gabaldon. When I became aware of "An Echo In the Bone" following the former story, I was ecstatic & purchased it at once!  As my title indicates, I am not reading it at breakneck speed.  Rather, I am savoring every page.  And, since it is over 1000 pages, it is quite a feast, indeed!  I cannot comment on the entire story as I am not all the way through.  I can only say that I am happily rejoined with Jamie and Claire and all the clansmen and women who are part of their lives.  Thank you, Diana, for another sequel to this soul-stirring drama!  I love it!

I am pretty obsessed with this series, and I love Claire and Jamie...that's why I have a hard time moving on to another series or book, they just don't compare!  I had a hard time connecting with this book, I actually didn't know if I could finish it.  It jumps around A LOT.  If I wanted entire chapters dedicated to what Lord John is doing, I would read his series.  I barely read any of the chapters dedicated to him OR William.  I was a bit more interested in William only because he is Jamie's son.  The part with Lord John and Claire while Jamie wasn't in the picture....unnecessary and unbelievable.  I really hope the next book doesn't jump around so much and I am immediately sucked into it like I was the prior books :-)

I read many reviews on Gabaldon's latest Jamie and Claire saga, An Echo in the Bone, before I purchased it, and they were mostly negative.  I DISAGREE!  This was written in her same wonderful style that made us all fall in love with the characters from day one.  Yes, many of the scenes were dragged-out, but every book in the series has had scenes that dragged-out; besides, I love these characters so much that I would rather have an extra 100 pages of dragged-out saga than 100 pages LESS of the story/book!  I am certain that Gabaldon is planning another book to the series, else she would not have left us hanging where she did...?
Sick to death of these stories and I will not read another.  How the hell could 2 people be so perfect.

Let me start by saying that I've read the Outlander series 3 times.  These are my favorite books.  I don't necessarily like the "detail" in the love scenes and feel they go too far but I skip through those parts.  With that said, I am really disappointed in this book.  It is very choppy with a lot of fluff and not much substance.  There is too much back and forth and I found myself skipping through a lot of Lord John and William chapters.  I NEVER DO THAT.  The ending to me was so out of character for Claire that I still can't believe it.  I hope the last book is better than this one.

I have thoroughly loved this series, but this last book was seriously lacking.  It doesn't even seem like it was edited properly. It is filled with grammatical errors and long passages that could have been trimmed.  There are many flat spots in the book.  The development of John Gray and his son William as characters in the American Revolution is boring and tedious. It is difficult to become attached to these characters. Even the parts that highlight Roger and Brianna are dull and silly.  If I were Diana Gabaldon, I would send this book back to the editor and try again.

It was not quite as good as the others.  I have read everything she has written and still felt left out trying to remember who had done what and what had happened in the past.  I agree the the shifting back and forth between family groups was a little disconcerting.  I also found quite a bit of repetition from previous books. She re-used some of her best lines.  I had to make myself continue to read at first and was glad I did because I liked the book, even though it was mildly disappointing.  I hope the next one comes soon, though.

I love the Outlander series. I especially like to listen to the audiobooks, but this one was a little hard to get through. The audio has 40 CD's which made me jump ahead because it was a little too long. I wish we could get a book about Jamie and Claire maybe once a year or every other year with 400 pages, rather than the long wait with 800-900 pages. I would like to know what happens with the cliffhangers in the story, but I'm afraid that if I have to wait a long period of time, it just won't matter.

Like some of the other reviewers here it me weeks to finish this book. Not because I was bored by it, but because like the other books, it is so large it is not easy to lug around. I had to leave it home and get to it when I had time. However, I loved it! I got so lost in it that when I was finally finished I was at lose ends for several days. I can't wait for the next installment but in the meantime I will reread books one through seven so I am up to speed when the story finally picks up again.

I've read the Outlander series at least three times. There were numerous parts of Gabaldon's books that made me roll my eyes in disbelief, but it's undeniable that the woman has a gift of telling a story; this last part of the series is no exception. What drove me to give this review was the ending--it left such a disagreeable taste in my mouth. I'm not sure if she should have lengthened the last 50 pages or should have just left them out. It was poorly executed and completely upsetting.

I love the Outlander series! I was introduced about 4 years ago by the daughter of one of my patients, who loaned me her paperback copy of Outlander, and I was immediately hooked.  This is the third, or maybe the fourth, time I have completed the series.  I can hardly stand the wait until June, when I am going to the reception in Dallas to get my autographed copy (YAY!!) of the next installment. And, oh my goodness, the series will be here in August!  Have to get my Starz going.......

I fell in love with this series from book one and persisted through all the books. Gabaldon is a terrific storyteller, and each book is filled with surprises and plot twists. All in all however they flow beautifully. I enjoyed the historical perspective and kept wondering why I didn't pay more attention in history class. Time travel, adventure, some violence, lots of love and a bit of history in a well written story. Who could ask for anything more?

I thought for a while that Diana had lost her way in the Firey Cross and then she began to come back in Breath of Snow & Ashes.  But now...Wow, she has recaptured the old magic.  Go back and read her first three books and you will see this how they all went...a roller coaster ride of thrills, quick turns, unexpected pop-ups of people, places and events.  And then to leave us hanging with more threads than ever!  My only regret is having to wait the two years or so it takes to get the next one.

Enjoyed this book much more than the last one.  There were many plot twists that made me stay up late to see what happened next.  Sometime it was hard to tell which character storyline I was reading though because the paragraph would start with 'I'.  However the story itself was so good it ddnt really matter.  However, this book had action and more character development.  I'm glad I stuck with the series and can't wait for the next one.

Although I can't seem to stop reading this series it needs better editing. It is very episodic, which is not a bad thing, and the writing is wonderful. There are just some episodes that don't at all advance the plot. Has the author never heard the expression "kill your darlings", and I don't mean the characters who are extraordinarily vivid. I will finish because I can't not, but I wish these books were shorter.

A continuation of the compelling series. For fans of the series you will not be disappointed. Engaging plot twists and turns combined with an excellent historical setting puts the reader feeling as if they live through the drama with the characters. If you liked the first few books keep reading. My only nit pick, the ending does not bring closure to any of the threads. I guess that's what gets us to buy book 8. Enjoy

Lots of answers are found in this book. However, it seems to get veeeerrry descriptive and then the last chapter everything happened at once and the book was over ! I couldn't get the next book ("Written in my own heart's blood") downloaded fast enough ! My heart is still pounding reading it and I am 1/2 way through it ! I am saying " Oh no" or something colorful throughout this book. Happy reading !

If there were 12 stars I would give this book twelve stars. This series is one of the most enjoyable reading experiences I've ever had and I read a lot! I have learned so much about Scotland and US history in a most appealing way. The characters become friends you love spending time with. I am anxiously waiting for the next book in the series and the Starz  movies coming out based on this series in August 2014.

I have read the whole series (plus Companion and one of Lord John's) and enjoy following the family through their various adventures. I purchased Echo in the spring, but saved it to read on a later trip to Scotland. Now I wait patiently for the next because Roger left totally unprepared, Jem is teetering on the edge, and Brianna is in peril. Can I wait three more years for the next? Wishing Diana all the best.

Diana Gabaldon never ceases to amaze me at her ability to weave fiction with true history.  She has an unique insight into human nature and her attention to detail is unrivaled!  Her books are never boring, as some historical novels can be.  This book equaled the books she wrote previously in this series.  I look forward to the next one.  Please tell me there will be another one!  She can't leave us hanging!

LOVE THIS SERIES!! Ok so everyone has doted on how much they love these books so I'm not going to add much to that. Just know I agree. My one complaint with this book is that I kept waiting for Daniel Bonner (from sara donati's Into the Wilderness) to show up. She, Sara, talks about the encounter she has with Ian, Jamie and Claire during a battle and that Jamie was injured. Why didn't Diana add that scene :(

What kind of ending was that? Not sure if Mrs. Gabaldon was burnt out at the end, ended abruptly without having some kind of closure. I understand there might be off shoots to new books, like Lord John Grey novellas but still there needs to be better closure to the characters you grow to love. Left me feeling like it was a two minute tickle and a squirt romp. Least favorite out of all the Outlander books.

I just finished reading all the other reviews and was happy to see I was not alone in my feelings about Gabaldon's latest book.  I found it difficult to follow and just as one story developed she'd jump to something else.  I would have liked a lot more of Jaime, Claire and Brianna and less of the historical lessons.  I've read all of the series, but I'll wait to see what the next book's reviews bring before I buy it!

I first started this novel right after it was published. I could not settle my mind into its pace. However, now in 2014, I found it engaging and interesting. Characters are vivid and real. Enough adventure and energy to be quite absorbing. I found myself thinking about the characters while involved in other activities. I would recommend it to readers who enjoy historical fiction.

This series was recommended by a co worker that read it years ago and decided to read again. I was happy to find that 8 books were completed so I was able to read straight through. I didn't realize there were more books to come so I am so disappointed that I have to wait to find out what happens next. I couldn't put the books down once I started. Hurry up Diana!

I wrote a previous review for this book that was not published. I wonder why? I am terribly disappointed in this author. I have followed this series and was looking forward to this new book. However, it did not live up to my expectations and, in fact, seems to be a Lord John book. What gives? I think the author should seriously think about how committed she is to these characters and decide if she wants to alienate her reader base any more than she has with this junk.

PLease do not let the review by Lehcarjt stop you from reading the book. It is very good. If you have read the other 6 books in thes series you will enjoy this one as well. The time line is correct. The history is interesting and yes it does not answer all of the questions but, there is to be book number 8 and possibly book 9 to come ( soon I hope).
This is my favorite author, I have all her books except a few, which I hope to still get, can't wait for her newest one, but it won't be out until later this year.
Can't wait for the next book to come out. I have read the series 3 times and still wish they would make a movie out of this series. Love it.
Excellent book. Really enjoyed the development of all the plots. Great strong characters and good historical facts. Can,t wait for Outlander 8.

The characters and multiple plot lines are compelling. I find myself totally drawn into their lives and stories. I find it difficult to put the book down while reading it and then slowing down toward the end because I don't want the story to end. I can't wait to read the next book in the series.

I wish I had the motivation to write how disappointed I am in this book. After suffering through 3/4 of the book...I quit. I have no interest in LJG or Wee Willie (what a poorly developed character). I won't write a saga because after 100's of wasted pages I'm sure nobody else wants to read any more about this saga.

Another great book in this incredibly good series. I cannot wait for the next one. I had to read the Lord John series to fill in the empty places that could not be filled with the Frasers. This was a great help to me as I was a little confused about where Percy fit into the story.  Now everything fits.

I love Gabaldon, I really do. But when I turned the page and saw that the book had ended......I yelled YOU HAVE GOT TO BE KIDDING ME....so loud that my son upstairs heard me. As usual, she has written another great book, but I could have tossed it across the room for how it ended

I have to say I loved that book and I was so happy that finally the author is back and the story is back. I sort of was upset with book 4, 5, and 6 and with this one, the story is interesting again and engaging and not too brutal, gruesome and sort of not Outlander. Not that I did not like the previous three books, but I was upset about them. Too much of Bree and Roger and sort of the story got lost. With this book, the story is again fascinating and I want to reread it again. I actually did not mind Bree and Roger and how they found themselves in 1980 with their kids, the way they adjusted to the life in Lallybroch and the situation in Scotland. Jem and Mandy are so lovely, I wish they were with Jamie and Claire. the author is so good with how she portrays children, I am really impressed. Also, William's story is great, nice to know him better and his journey of discovery whose his true father was. The return to Lallybroch was good, with Ian's death and Leoghaire always causing rift raft between Jamie and Claire. I really do not know if Jamie has ever been attracted to her, kissing someone is not exactly an attraction, but momentary need, but you never know. And finally, Jamie and Claire, their awesome love and life. When she had to go to America by herself I sort of felt something might go wrong, I do not like them apart. And when she found out from Lord John, Jamie was dead, it was horrible, even though I knew he was not because they were late for the ship. I was shocked what transpired between Claire and Lord John. Kind of could not find myself. I understand, but.....weird, somehow. It will cause many problems, I guess. I like Lord John and the way he loves Jamie, the way he respects and likes Claire and loves William. There are a lot of good things in the book. It is fast reading and very engaging. The ending is great, the way Jamie reacts to the carnal knowledge of Lord John's of his wife simply saying Oh and why.

I adore Diana Gabaldon. I flat-out adore her. I've devoured 6 of her books thus far and look forward to more. As a writer myself I have to say the pace of this book does indeed drag and the character arcs can be confusing r/t timelines. I can only speak to what I personally found problematic: lonnnnnnnnnnng, excruciatingly described details of historic battles, and digressions into complement characters that weren't absolutely germaine to the overall story, IMHO. I hang on pretty much every word this woman crafts; her descriptions of character's moods & actions are a superlative only a short list of writers can be credited with. I have come to feel Claire & Jamie are 'family'; I watch the tv show like a fiend, LOL, unplugging the phone so no one can interrupt my time travels. :):):)  I've seen all her appearances and I have the privilege of chatting with her on Twitter. But this book……is heavy ( not talking about the weight) in terms of historic battle detail I'm not convinced the book wouldn't be better without. Because she has been so crazy-successful with this series, I kinda wonder if her editors don't maybe purposefully edit less, just because they want fans to have plenty to get their teeth into ??? Just a thought. I am melancholy to say, I too am disappointed in this book and it breaks my heart. Like so many others here, a visit with Claire & Jamie, Roger & Brianna is the last thing I do at night. Ms Gabaldon's books have lived on my nightstand for over a year now and I cherish them. I've stuck with this book out of immense respect for her, but very uncharacteristically have begun reading other books in between. I see that many others here have done the same. Hoping Ms. Gabaldon can glean some learning from the input of her devoted and adoring fan base. I am knocked out by her great big ole' acutely attuned brain & massive vocabulary, but this book is not up to the standards of all those which preceded it,I am quite sad to say. Despite this review, I do look forward to more from this prolific and gifted author, however.

What can I say I loved this book as I have the entire series. I actually think I am learning more about American history from these books then I did in high school...lol. Well I suppose I had my mind on boys and rock and roll concerts back then...lol. The books also focuses on many different story lines and yet they are all tied together as well there is cast of many in this one so be prepared of course Jamie and Claire and there unconditional love for one another and now twelve years have gone by and in the middle of the American Revolution too. Brianna and Roger and family go back to the 20th century for Health reasons and not easy to readjust to the 20th century from the 18th century. There is also the struggles of Fergus family and of course there is Ian one of my favorite characters and the many changes he goes through. Yes Jamie's son William and Lord John Grey are also in this storyline. William is now an English soldier and of course Jamie is a rebel patriot Colonial in the American army....could it get any more dramatic father and son on opposing sides. Also some new delightful characters I really enjoyed are Denny and his sister Rachel whom is a Army doctor for the Americans and are Quakers. I really found this storyline interesting and enjoyable. A few famous names in American history also make a few cameo appearances in this book Ben Franklin, Benedict Arnold to name a couple but I don't want to give much away if this isn't your tenth time reading this book. All I can say is I loved it and I a, looking forward to her new book Written In Your Own Hearts Blood that hopefully will be out before the New Year. This writer is brilliant....one smart cookie for sure. I have enjoyed this entire series immensely and look forward to future book as many of you know she truly has the gift of storytelling...I am always amazed by the details as well as the storyline. I give this book ten stars if I could! I loved it!!!!

I haven't read anything of Diana's since "A breath of Snow and Ashes", have been engaged with novels and characters more in keeping with current day mysteries.  I read several of these reviews before I read "An Echo in the Bones" on my Kindle and pomised myself that I must read more slowly (it was tough to bring back old details) than I would have with the hardbacks which I raced through and realized that I'd missed a lot of detail.  Reading at a more liesurely pace was worth it.  The old details came back and the multiple story lines stayed intact, yet somwhat relevant to the whole.  I thought several times that the William & Lord John adventures, other than where they intersect with Claire and Jamie might have been better served as a separate piece, but that is my only real criticism other than the fantastical coincidences of characters' paths crossing - a little tough to accept so many.  I too, would prefer more of the "story" than the surrounding historical details, but with all the research that's been done, it would be a shame not to share it, if only for those who are uneducated regarding the times.  The fact that we are left hanging with the Roger/Briana phase promises that there will be another book; obviously there will be more of Claire and Jamie and the American Revolution and the development of the relationship with William and we won't be too surprised if there is a full family reunion in the works at some point.  I'm a bit sorry that I don't have the hardback to add to my Gabaldon collection, but given the strain that some readers expressed on its size :o), and my previous experiences of trying to manage the huge texts of Diana's stories, I have no regrets that my copy will remain on my Amazon library shelf.  I just hope we don't have to wait 5 years for the next offering!!  Story telling at its best never grows old; as time goes on, I've learned to savor these intertwined stories more slowly, the better to remember and enjoy them.

Too much was left hanging in this book.  It's obviously set up for a sequel as are all her other books in this series.  But this one was all over the place.  I had a hard time staying with Brianna and Roger.  A few too many time travelers for me.

The Outlander series has given me more insight into History than I ever learned in school. In "An Echo In The Bone" Diana Gabaldon has left me enthralled, dangling, and waiting impatiently for Book #8, unfortunately not due out for another year.

I liked this book, no question about it. I have gone through her books looking forward to the next epic saga in the adventures of Jamie and Claire. In this book, it appears DG is veering off a bit to allow for the story line to pick up other influential characters, such as Brianna and Roger and their family, and (wee) Ian and his life unfolding, and William (Ransom), Jamie's son being raised by Lord John Grey. After all, in spite of their seemingly charmed lives, Jamie and Claire are not going to live forever. Jamie is what, in his 50's now? with Claire a few years older. And Jamie still leading troops and soldiering, and up to now, he has been lucky not to be seriously injured.  However, the storyline tended to jump about, especially during the Revolutionary War - and it was more of a chore to follow the story than in the previous books. Personally, I think this book could have been edited a bit better, as sometimes less is actually more. However, it didn't stop me from jumping right into Book 8, Written In My Own Heart's Blood and now I'm waiting for the next novel, which could be a few years. Patience, patience. As for the Starz programming featuring these books - well, now that I've ready the books, I'm not sure I really want to see the movies. I don't want to see Jamie being flogged, or the Highlander men being massacred at Culloden. It's already in my head, and I don't want to see it on the screen. I know someone that won't watch the movies on Starz as she has already read the books, and she has a vision of what Jamie and Claire should look like in her head. She said watching the movies might disappoint her. I can see her point!

I couldn't put this book down, but felt it needed to be edited down. When I wasn't reading the book I was thinking about what would happen next. The ending was very abrupt. Some story lines were not resolved in any way shape or form.

This is one of Gabaldon's better books in this series. She creates an intriguing tale filled with  unforgettable characters while taking the reader through the18th  century world of Scotland and America
I Have read the books in this saga over and over. I am overjoyed to be able to start reading Written in my Own Heart's Blood! I love escaping into the world of adventures created by Diana Gabaldon.
I loved the series, however An Echo In The Bone was a BIG Disappointment! It didn't even seem to have been written by the same author  What a poor ending for this series of exceptional books!
I have read every book from the series and find it fascinating and informative. The history, the science the characters become part of your life. Can't wait for the next book in July!

I love the Outlander series and in the past felt like I was losing a friend when I would get to the end of one of the books. Until this book, "The Fiery Cross" was my least favorite book in the series. "An Echo in the Bone" was one of the most difficult books I have read in a long time.  I normally finish one of Diana's books in a week.  This particular book has been a real struggle to read and took me over a month to finish it. Only in the last two days did it get interesting and then I couldn't believe the way we are left hanging at the end.  I frankly found myself skimming the pages and not really reading most of the parts with William, Lord John, and the war.  I did enjoy the Ian and Rachel storyline. Will I read the next book?  Yes, because I want to know what happens to Claire, Jamie, Roger and Brianna and the kids. I am also interested in what happens with Ian and Rachel. I would be happy if we never heard about Lord John and William again. Sorry Diana, not only did Jamie miss the boat at the end of the book, but you missed the boat when you wrote this one!  I hope the next book will tie up all of the loose ends and be like the earlier books in the series were.
A wonderful insight Into the settler's involvement in the American Revolution... And the difficulties they had to endure. ( as viewed by someone of the twentieth century).

Reading this book for the second time while I wait for my husband to complete Written in My Own Heart's Blood - can't wait to get to the end.  I let him get a head start so we should finish about the same time today!  Things never go as planned for Claire and Jamie and this book is no exception.  The Revolutionary War is heating up and there are redcoats and rebels everywhere.  it's hard to know who to trust and they have to make their way to the coast and eventually to Scotland to pick up Jamie's printing press in Edinburgh and drop off Ian to his mother at Lallybroch.  Needless to say, I am two thirds of the way through the book and they haven't made it yet!  There's always lots of patients for Dr. Claire and lots of commands for Jamie to take over somehow.  Plenty of conflict and questions.  Hope Book Eight answers a few of them!  LOL!  If you've never read Diana Gabaldon, I recommend starting at the beginning with Outlander and reading the whole series in order!  You may not go through the standing stones like Claire but you will disappear into the 17th century in your head for several hours for each book - they are all about 800 pages long!  Happy reading!

What can I say? The latest installment in the continuing Jamie and Claire family saga answers some questions, further develops relationships between the characters, concludes some cliff hangers, and generally delights in its far reaching detailed depiction of life during the American Revolution, and in contemporary (1980's Scotland) It is best appreciated by fans of the series, but it can be enjoyed without having read the prior novels. It defies easy categorizations, as it is romance, science fiction, mystical fantasy, historical novelization of real events, and all in all gripping reading. It is meant to be savored bit by bit, not devoured in one sitting. (Nice job of that if you can do all 800+ pages in one go!) Some people may find it slow and meandering, but that is its joy. Diana Gabaldon provides enough change-ups and plot twists and surprising developments so satisfy anyone. It is not meant to be the end of the series, so many elements are not nicely tied up and resolved. Of course, to wait four or more years for the next one is not an easy task. Idea! Re-read the series from the beginning! Many have done so many times. I thoroughly enjoyed this book.
I can't get enough of this series. I have spent 2 years reading it and will probably read the first book again while I am waiting for the release of the next book!

I have no real words of wisdom to impart here but I just had to say I adore these 7 books. I feel so lucky that I just discovered them now through my book club. If I had to wait 3 years between the volumes I would have been devastated. I was able to read all 7 books in about a 6-8 week period. I was obsessed with the characters. Of course Jamie is gorgeous and everything you pretty much want in a man (handsome, loving, kind, intelligent and protective) but Claire is such a wonderful character as she is strong and modern. I just hope Gabaldon comes out with her 8th book and hopefully her last (in the Jamie/Claire saga) early next year as it is hard to wait. Truly when the book was over, I felt I lost some friends. I do think book 8 should be the final one. I loved the characters and most of the new ones but I think the fans have a right to know that it ends, happily or not, it ends. We know it can't actually end happily but it can end satisfactory to all the fans who have read these over the last several years. These books are large enough (page wise) that she could tie up all the loose ends in this last book. I would highly recommend these books.

I have listened to all of Diana Gabaldon's books except "A Breath of Snow and Ashes". That may well be the difference between the reviews I saw of the printed word and the more positive reviews of the audiobook. I enjoyed all of the audiobooks far more than the written word in this series, yet I am a hardcore hardcover book lover. But these books, read by Davina Porter deliver a stunning and powerful story every single time, even if the subject matter IS re-inflating a collapsed lung in the 18th century. Of all of the audiobooks I have listened to, and there are dozens and dozens now, these lend themselves to this format more than all of them. The story IS detailed in its telling, and it is even tedious at times, but it is always worth it. Anything less would be simply a story, one that could be told, if one had little time to bother with it, in only a few chapters. Why do that? Why shorten it to just the bare bones? Truly, the devil IS in the details, and no book I have ever read is more suited to be heard. If you love the series and were disappointed in this one, try listening to it!

I am a literature snob. It makes me shudder to admit I have now read 7 of the 8 novels in the Outlander series. And still, once I start I cannot put them down. I have fallen in love with the characters.  I am am curious about them. When not reading one of the books, I wonder about their well being. This book was particularly good. Like the others, it takes you down dead ends, makes you meet characters you could care less about, and it forces you to get to know characters who come and go never to be seen or heard from again. It over-loads you with botanical minutiae. However, unlike several of the other books in this series, it does these things to a tolerable and not an intolerable degree. The book otherwise is mesmerizing. The author's characters are so alive and so vibrant. The history they live in is so rich and passionate. Because of these books I will be taking my first trip to Scotland this summer. I know so much more about Scotland -and the history of my own country from the eyes of its Scottish immigrants, than I did before I started this series. To learn while having so much fun? Here's to a very savvy author!

I really enjoyed this new addition to the Outlander Series as much as the rest of the books.  Jamie, Claire and family continue with the wild adventures through time.  Yes, the book leaves quite a few cliffhangers but I loved them and can not wait to see how these issues are resolved.  With this family story we could go on and on forever. It seems there was not as much lovin' going on in this book as it was difficult for privacy amid all the adventures.  And then there was the kinky paring at the end which I totally understood and approved of.  It adds yet another relational aspect to these characters IMO. I can see Jem becoming the star of a new set of this series and we haven't even touched on the little girl's abilities yet.  So keep writing DG and I would be happy if you have this as a lifelong series for me.  As for those of you wanting a "true ending" forget it!  I read a dozen books in one series and would have read more if the author had not died.  Yes, the book is heavy--go exercise!  Get in shape so you can read the next book too.

I am a great fan of the Outlander series so it's hard for me to be critical about any of Diana Gabaldon's books. I zipped through this one and it left me wanting more. However, this was largely due to a couple of major story lines (and characters) left hanging. I don't recall Ms. Gabaldon being such a tease. It was like watching the old Saturday matinees which always ended "to be continued," except next Saturday I won't be any more enlightened than I am now. MORE, we must have MORE! You can tell this book was written very piecemeal. It doesn't flow as well as "Drums" or "Breath of Snow," nor do the pieces always make sense when fit back together (materials lost in a shipwreck magically appear later in the book). The tradeoff is, though, that Ms. Gabaldon has created many new and interesting characters so there is LOTS going on, making it a thumping good read. In this she does not disappoint. In addition, there is a great deal more medical detail and pharmacognosy which is a particular area of interest for me. Oh, and did I mention the sex?
Diana Gabaldon has an amazing style of writing... I came across this series about 6 months ago and since then everything I try to read comes up lacking!

I have just finished reading An Echo in the bone.  I have to admit I was disappointed with it.  There was way too much detail about the wars and surgery technique.  It was almost like the book was about that and just inserted Clair and Jaime into it. I have to admit I skimmed alot of pages and putting down the book was NO problem.  The end which could of been expanded was so choppy! There were spots I felt could of had more info. It's like after 400 pages it was better hurry up and finish this!  This book could of easily been condensed into 200 pages easily.  I'm not a fan of Lord John and only read the first book in the series.  I see another is coming out.  Please Diana go back to this series and finish it and leave Lord John alone!

First of all, I love the Jaime and Claire saga overall. I admit that I do have to make an emotional commitment for each installment due to the length, but usually that is not a problem because DG writes in such a beautiful way that I fall into the time, place and relationships.  I purchased the hardback version of An Echo in the Bone immediately and made it midway through, but due to time and daily distractions just couldn't seem to continue.  As with a few other reviewers, I couldn't track the jumps between the three major story themes.  I would occasionally pick it up and try to get back into the book.  About a month ago, I noticed the unabridged audio version at my local library branch, narrated by Davina Porter.  I drive quite a bit for work and within three weeks, with Ms. Porter's help, I happily completed this very long audio book.  Through her wonderful vocal interpretations (she's truly gifted) I was again captivated and carried along on the Fraser's journey.  Personally, I enjoy the detail DG puts into her characters' experiences--even for dear Rollo.
Diana Gabaldon continues from page 1 in the same suspenseful vein as the previous books in the series. Fantastic understanding of life in the period.

Of course. I love them all. I did find however that the switch between narrators, sometimes within the same chapter, a bit confusing. I will say that the narrative made such a numbers of narrators necessary and did help to round out the story in a way that one point of view would not. As the daughter of an American Southerner and a British expatriate, I was born and grew up in New England with two points of view regarding American history (besides that which I was taught in school) Now I have a third. I am a college graduate and consider myself well read, but found I must often look up words with which I was unfamiliar. For this exercise I thank the author because I feel that my education has been broadened. My father, long dead, was the last person I knew who spoke the Gaelic. I wish I could pronounce some of the phrases used by various characters. All in all, I am addicted to the Outlander series and have been reading the straight through, to the detriment of housework, meal preparation, and early bedtime. What a wonderful addiction!

After the first novel, I expected none of the sequels would live up to the original (as is true with so many good series).  While it is true that the first novel will always be my favorite (since it was where Gabaldon's own style and creativity were first exposed to me, and first times are always special), she has continually met or exceeded expectations by weaving a deliciously absorbing saga with a uniformly engrossing quality. I have stopped holding my breath and waiting for the good part to be over... and have come to trust in her ability to remain creative and keep me entranced in her story.  Her characters have come to be like good friends to me.  This has never happened to me before - while I deeply enjoy reading and am happily entertained by many books, I have NEVER before been brought to trust an author to continually provide such consistently excellent material as Gabaldon.  Couldn't be happier - The Outlander Series is uniquely wonderful and I look forward to continuing with it as long as possible!!

I love this series and will be going through withdrawal symptoms soon as I am now reading the current edition.  There is so much contained in the Outlander series, Adventure, extremely well written historical timelines in various countries at various times all woven together with a magical side which has enabled Claire to travel between times thanks to the stones, or doorways which transport the ones who are able 200 years in the past and back to the future with a great deal of possible harm if not done correctly.  There is everything contained in these books, romance, mystery, fantasy, history, war and extremely well written well researched writing by an excellent author.  I love learning and gaining more understanding of the Scottish Highlanders who fought for independence,  the early Americans who fought for freedom in the Revolutionary War and the British who fought to hang on to both. Lots of character building and depth.  I will not give away any secrets... you will have to read discover them yourself.
I read nothing but the Outlander series for four months, and I wasn't bored! Great author. Well worth reading if you like historical fiction.
Diana Gabaldon's research is spot on and even though this is fiction it's very believable.  It's a great read and I enjoyed it thoroughly.

Usually I fly right through the Outlander books, but this one took a while to finish reading.  It seemed to "stall" during the Revolutionary War battles, specifically Fort Ticonderoga.  While Galbadon continues to capture the essence of her characters wherever the are and turns their daily lives into something exciting and intriguing, I think she spent too much time on trivial matters in this book, and it was choppy.  It flitted from Claire and Jamie to William (Jamie's son) to Lord John Gray and his family - sick brother and wounded nephew) to Ian and his adventures with Rollo, trying to find Rachael, and so on..... Nevertheless, the end of the book all came together to set us up for the next one, which I will of course read as soon as it is released (1 more week).  It did leave us hanging, especially on the whereabouts of young Jemmy.  I'm looking forward to the Outlander Series scheduled for TV this summer.  I want to see these characters brough to life!

Diana does not disappoint in her 7th installment of the Outlander series.
