With twists and turns, questions answered and more questions raised, the drama continues with the supreme depth that you've come to expect from Diana.  I must admit, she's never left us with a cliffhanger before and this one ends with massive questions to be answered with such a wait for the next installment.  Fortunately now,  we have MOBY to dive into.  If you've read Diana before, you will be reassured with her luscious storytelling ability.  If you haven't...This is a fantastic story, but you need to start at the beginning! Investment in time...but so worth it.  Absolutely the best books I have ever read.  They are so full of detail and intriguing storylines, you will fall in love with the characters, the homesteads, the settings.  You will be unable to put these down.  And for some, Diana will spoil you, as she has me, a day reading other similar novels won't even compare. Enjoy...

I have read all the other books in this series 2x and can't believe how much I disliked this one.If it wasn't this particular series I would have stopped reading it.There are way too many different story lines.I found myself reading ahead in each chapter to see who it was about.There is way too much about Lord John Grey and William. Claire marrying and having relations with John Grey about a month after she thinks Jamie is dead!? No matter what the circumstances.I just don't see it.If you feel you have to read this volume, know that it does get better ( not great) starting on about page 600!I pre ordered this book for my mother also and am wondering whether or not to give her a summary ( if I can!)instead of letting her try to plod her way thru this.

Diana Gabaldon never disappoints in her "Outlander" series. The novels are full of information, history, romance and story. This particular episode was a bit more difficult to get into as it didn't give as much of a summary of past episodes. If you hadn't read any of her previous novels in this series, you would have been completely lost. It did end in a cliffhanger which is a bit disappointing as the writer herself admitted it takes her three years to write one of these novels. Three years is a long time to wait to find out what happens. But I know for certain I will be waiting in the end and will pick up the next novel in the series. If you haven't read this series, do so. It is well worth the read. The books are very very long though and not the type of thing you can carry with you on vacation. If you do want to take on vacation, get it on Kindle instead.

This is the only Gabaldon book I was unable to finish.  I made it to within a hundred pages of the end, and just couldn't force myself to go on.  The book was so slow, boring, and filled with extraneous historical detail (especially the battles), that it was a headache to read.  A Breath of Snow and Ashes (the previous book in this series) was brilliant!  One of the best volumes next to Book One Outlander.  To follow that up with this continuation is shocking.  I would stop reading and not come back to the book for days because I was so bored with it and irritated.  I finally called it quits and moved on to something else.  I'm now in the opening chapters of Written in My Own Heart's Blood (the next book in the series Book 8) and it's already better than An Echo In The Bone.  I hope this volume is just a blip in the series.  Not engaging at all.  Read a summary of the plot online and skip forward to the newest book.

If you are a true lover of the Outlander Series you will definitely love the Reunion with the Fraser/Mackenzie clan!  This was like a welcome home celebration after a long absence from your family.  Some people complained about how the book went from Jamie and Claire, to Ian, to Bree and Roger, to Lord John Grey and William and so on and so forth.  I don't believe it was choppy at all.  I think she seamlessly sewed the pieces of the story together for readers to catch up on all that had been happening in the life of Jamie and Claire's progeny and they people who are closely impacted by them.  All I can truly say (without giving away the book) is that this book is awesome.  It's filled with such action, heartfelt emotions, and you just can't help but be lost in the book and fill like your a fill-in character seeing everything from a birds view.

I recently finished all seven books of the Outlander series. With the exception of book 2, which I found a bit slow and repetative, I thoroughly enjoyed them all.  My disappointment came at the end of this book, An Echo In The Bone, when after being a part of these characters lives for 30 years and preparing myself to say goodbye, I find that there are still a lot of loose ends to be tied up - in book 8, due out in fall of 2013. Still, I highly recommend this series and look forward to my continued journey with them. I will likely start to re-read the series from the beginning before book 8 is released to refresh my memory and get back into the mood of the books and the lives of the characters. These are large, long books with a lot of Scottish and Early American history  blended with a ficticious cast of endearing family members and some vile viilans, but well worth the commitment.
A slow read, because of so many side stories.  Too many of these stories stretch credibility.  The plot is very convoluted.

I am an avid fiction reader, reading a broad spectrum of genres. Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series is without doubt the best fiction I have ever read. She truly brings her characters to life and this series encompasses not only historical fiction but suspense, drama, romance, time travel and powerful statements about the human condition then and now. She is extremely creative but has also done in-depth research to produce the finest current literature available. There is a richness and complexity to her stories that make them enjoyable reading multiple times. I have just finished reading An Echo in the Bone for a second time and found it highly entertaining and exciting this time too. The books are lengthy but, after reading the first few pages, you are grateful it won't end too soon. My only caveat as with most series, Start with Book 1, Outlander and read them in sequence.

Spoilers....I finally finished it after almost 2 weeks!  I agree with many of the other reviews as it wasn't holding my interest like the other Outlander novels did.  Defintely not enough Jaime and Claire and way too much Lord John and historical overviews.  I also feel DG rushed the ending.  There was way too much in the last 100 pages after such a slow moving beginning and middle.  It didn't read right!  The whole Lord John and Claire sex situation is just too unbelievable.  I cannot possibly imagine her having sex with John with Jaime being "dead" a week to her knowledge.  It doesn't fit Claire at all. The marriage I could accept as necessary, but the other stuff - no way?!  However it is DG's story to tell and we're merely along for the ride.  EITB was the loop de loop...I feel a little unsettled!

I didn't give this one 5 stars simple because the ending - The author has said it takes her 4 years to write these big books - and if I would've had to wait 4 years to read the next one, I might've resorted to Stephen King's imagination to get the writer to hurry it up!  (Jk.)  Luckily, I discovered this series late and by the time I read this book the next one in line was already printed (and on my kindle awaiting me.)  The actual story line is just as great and enthralling as her other books but having read this book and the next so close together I found my memory being fogged up about where one book ended and the other began...I do LOVE all of these books in the Outlander series and will recommend them to everyone - but this recommendation stands with one caveat - make sure you have the next book on stand by and ready to read when you finish this one!

If you are a fan of the Outlander series, you don't need my recommendation for this book.  If you aren't already a fan, I recommend you start at the beginning with the book Outlander.  It is an epic story of a time travelling family that has two lives, one in the US and Scotland 1945-1970's and all of the historical events in that time frame. The second life is in the US and Scotland 1743-1780 or so. It is a historically accurate series, very well written and totally engaging.  Starz is doing a miniseries on the book Outlander, which will begin again April 4 2015.  Something for everyone.  History, Romance, Adventure, Medical history, herbology, and a well rounded sexcapade.  I don't really recommend this book as a stand alone book, there are too many characters, too much history.  Definitely recommend you start with Outlander.
Great as always, just makes Jamie and Clare live on and on. Great story line and a always entertaining.Keep it up.
I'd hope the end of this book would wrap the story....I felt it was time, instead there is another cliff hanger.
Can't wait for the next book. Just as good as the rest of the series. This one does have a few cliff hangers.
An Echo in the Bone is one more in the Outlander series that is a must read.  Diana Gabledon does it again..

I love Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series, of which this is one of the volumes. If you have not read the earlier books in the series, don't cheat yourself by diving into the story at this point (unless you are stuck in an airport with a huge delay and/or a very long flight in coach, and this is the only book in the bookstore you would even consider buying. Otherwise, wait and begin at the beginning with Outlander.) The series is a long, lovely, wonderful story with characters you will love and historical detail that will make you want to pick up history books for supplemental reading. How she did all her research is a mystery to me (how did you do it all, Diana?) Not only is she a fine writer, but you will fall in love with her characters, but now. I am just repeating myself.

It helps if you have read the previous tens of thousands of pages of this series. Otherwise I doubt the book will make much sense. But for fans of Diana Gabaldon...well...we want even more!  If you have stumbled on to this book go back and start with Outlander and plan on spending a large part of your life reading this wonderful series which has been going on for over twenty years. If you have been reading this series you will get this book no matter what anyone says - and you probably already have read it. It is not the best of the series (those were the first ones I think) but it is still a fun romp. I have both the hardbound book and the Kindle edition. I found with such a large book the Kindle edition was a bit more enjoyable to read from a physical point of view.

She's done better, and she's done worse (Voyager in general was a tad overdone for my taste ... as was Fiery Cross).  I agree it's jumpy for a while.  Some folks may wish she didn't spend time inside other character's heads (I'd like a little time inside Jamie's head though), but I think Diana's trying to coax you to get a little closer to the younger characters -- perhaps trying to pave the way for a different series based on their continuing stories when it comes time for Claire and/or Jamie to kick the bucket.  (I know, I know, "bite your tongue", but ....)  Maybe she's not actually giving up on the series after the eighth book.  There are a few folks who've been hyper-critical of this, but she's done it in the past -- at least since Brianna became an adult.

As I scan the reviews here, I see many points for and against, and realize, as always, it comes down to personal taste.  Yes, there are many stories running through this novel.  Some people will hate that.  Being true to life, I enjoy that aspect of it.  Like others, I'm not so interested in the Lord John episodes, and could have done without them.  But as always with Diana's books, I enjoy the detail, the descriptions that put me right there, and the history woven through the story.  I have enjoyed some books in the series more than this one, but I enjoyed this one quite a bit, too, and really like having a book that lasts for weeks, instead of being over and done with in a day or two.

I can't believe I'm still reading this series, when I said I wouldn't. I just need to know where Jaime & Claire end up. As I've said before, It's as if at least two people wrote these books. One person who puts words together so beautifully and full of depth and then another who fills in the spaces with the ability of a novice with a bad imagination. This writer seems to have a fixation with odors and describes them in detail with each person and location, most of which are unpleasant. Also the words blushing, flushing and turning red are used throughout the books when there's a conversation between people. REALLY? If pages needed to be filled, she might have written an end to some of the story lines she left unfinished in this book. What a chopped off ending.

As Ms. Galbadon's former novels, Echo in the. Bone has provided tremendous adventure. The enduring love and great friendship between Claire and Jamie grows as time progresses. The developing characters throughout these books have won hearts as well as those dirty characters we have grown to strongly dislike. The play of Clair and Jamie between their daughter, Brianna and her husband and grandchildren creates tension and drama. Even though this younger family has returned to modern times there has been a message from the parents through the ages. Ms. Galbadon's skill in creating those agonizing cliff hangers will be delayed a few more months. However, this should be satisfied by the Outlander series produced by Starrz coming in the summer. Enjoy the adventure.

Yes, this is not great literature.  But it is loads of fun.  Dana Gabaldon does a superb job of taking us into the past to observe Scottish and American daily life and history through the eyes of her time traveling Fraser family.  She conjures up all the small details of daily life without modern conveniences while spinning a sexy, adventurous, rip roaring story.  How do you light a candle if you don't even have matches?  Where does dinner come from? What is it like in wartime when good neighbors have to choose sides?  OK, now I read other reviews from disappointed readers.  I was not disappointed.  I actually enjoy picking up on the lives of the many other characters.  How long can she just write about Clare and Jamie Fraser?

My daughter has told me for years how much she enjoys this series, but it didn't sound interesting to me.  However, when she was so excited that there was a television show based on the book, I decided to watch it.  I was immediately hooked and ordered the series of books on Kindle.  That was September.  It is now December, and I am reading  the next to last book, Echo in the Bone.  Like any soap opera, once you get into the storyline, its like visiting your other family.  I think the series is historically accurate.  It's interesting to read how the main character uses her modern day medical knowledge to care for people in the 18th century with what is available in the way of herbal medicines, and  what she can concoct.

William's journeys across the Colonies at the behest of Richardson are quite a revelation, as is his interaction with one Denys Randall-Isaac. What I found even more interesting is his interaction with Ian Murray, who has returned to his uncle and aunt, and is now a tracker for the rebels, even as William is on the side of the King. Jamie and Claire begin with a straightforward plan to sail to Scotland and retrieve his printing press...but who was it who said something about the plans of mice and men going oft agley? Which is just what happens in this case... Roger and Brianna face several challenges when they return to their own time; they cannot be certain of their safety, even in a supposedly law-abiding society...

I read all the reviews on this site for "An Echo In The Bone" and there were so many negative reviews that I almost passed on it. I had a pretty good idea of the gist by compiling in my mind the summaries posted and decided there was enough substance to warrant reading this book.  Don't let the naysayers discourage you; after all, you've already invested countless hours reading this remarkable series, why not a few more hours and a modest investment to purchase the paperback from Amazon as I did. I'm so glad I read it, and I look forward to the next in the series.  I'm 66-years-old and hopefully I'll still be alive when it comes out.

I've read and loved this entire series, mainly for the characters I've come to love (Jamie & Claire) within their historical context(s). What I have not enjoyed in the series has been the number of background characters and storylines and the time the author spends on them. 'An Echo' is Gabaldon's only book I found myself paging through, looking for the handful of characters I care about to reappear out of the maze of others whose names and stories I could not even keep straight. Readers are asked to hold their collective breaths longer than I found pleasurable.

I loved the story through eight books!  Then it is though she just dropped the energy to finish.  She dropped the story of completely of Roger going through the stones to find his son...no satisfaction!  They left the grandson stranded in a cave in a train in the dark!  No story there after developing it for a long time and they left Jamie running with no satisfaction of a relation with Claire...Long and sometimes boring with a touch of tedium but totally not a satisfying ending!  All those hours ...longest book out of eight and a stupid and cliff with which to end a series...now..she gives us details in more books?  No good!  Don't spend your time on this series at all!  Very mad!  Money and time wasted!

I don't know how many hours I've invested reading the Outlander series, but it's still worth it. Some series get stale after a while and you finish them only because you've already made such a huge investment. This is not one of those series. Gabaldon has almost done the impossible by still keeping this series so fresh. I look so forward to becoming reacquainted with Claire and Jamie each time. They are one of the great married couples in literature. My only qualm with this book is one interaction between Claire and Lord John toward the end of the volume. I just didn't find it believable. One scene out so many, however, didn't tarnish it, and I look forward to the next installment.

I could never give Diana less than 3 stars. Her body of work is inspiring and meticulous. However, I have to say this novel was not one of my favorites. It was a little choppy and not enough of Jaime and Claire. I wasn't as offended by the surprise ending as some. It almost felt like time was warped and the characters were existing in a reality where all of their actions were completely out of character. I hope this is fleshed out in the next book. I don't care if it takes another 2 years. I want to give Diana time to create another masterpiece. I have a feeling that this book was rushed and I'd hate for that to happen again. I'm looking forward to the next installment.

I agree with many other readers that this started slow, but once it got going, I really enjoyed it.  I also agree somewhat that the story was a bit choppy and I saw sections that could be cut without detracting from the plot.  I totally disagree with the reviewers who don't want the details of life in the 1770 but want "the story".  Since this is a book about time travel, the details of the 1770 are part of the story.  I think the historical accuracy and time travel is what saves these books from simply being romance novels.  If you don't like history, why would you read a novel about time travel?  I also find the details of Claire's physician work fascinating.

i got a little confused in the different view point at first but became accustomed to it. At the end of every book in the series there is a cliff hanger, some small and some so big that you will feel that you will go crazy . This book has many cliff hangers from everyone's viewpoint. i have so many questions that i dont even know where to begin. i am begging for another book soon so i can see what is next on the adventure. it was great i loved it but i wish that it was longer and a few BIG things answered

I can't even begin to describe how much I love this series. I literally stopped reading all my favorite authors while consuming these books. I can't imagine how the author can write so well for so many pages, and always leave me reaching for the next book. I am a life long reader of every genre. I have probably read more than 12000 books in my life. These just grabbed a hold of me. I love the characters, the twists, the hopes and dreams. Every time I think I have read  everything that could ever happen with Jamie, and Claire, something entirely new happens. I don't know how the series will end, but I honestly hope it doesn't. Love these so much!!!

I've been a fan of Diana Gabaldon's for years & her "Dragonfly in Amber" historical fiction series is one of my favorites of all time! Her books are always full of excitement, action & mystery, as well as being great love stories. Every time I've read one of these books, it leaves me "on the edge of my seat" wanting to continue the journey with Jaimie and Claire & I can't wait until the next one is published!!! I've already read the last in the series & have been waiting & waiting for the next new book. I sure hope she gets it finished soon!!! This one was no exception to the rest in the series. It keeps you involved right through the last page.

The Outlander series, of which Echo in the Bone is the seventh volume, is a very well-written series that combines historical fiction (18th century) with time travel--but is not as gimmicky as that implies.  The concept works well because of the excellent historical research and the extremely well-drawn characters. The love story of Jamie and Claire is the primary thread, but numerous subplots and characters bring the era alive. If you have not read any in the series, be sure to begin with Outlander (Vol. One) and work your way through the other seven volumes.  They are all very long books, but they are quite addictive and well worth the time.

This is the last book in Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series, which I have been reading off and on for two years now. I find myself trying to slow the 'consumption' of this last novel a little - it's a great series and I will be sorry to have it end. Specifically, Echo in the Bone has some great action, and intrigue as well as the being back to the split storytelling of life in two different times (some of the characters being in present day Scotland, the others in America 200 years ago). It's another great book from Diana Gabaldon. I think she's an amazing writer, having been able to spin this tale across 7 novels - and ALWAYS you want more.
Not quite as good as previous books, love her detail usually but not as much in this one

I love the twists in this book. Diana has ruined me for most other writers. I loved all her books but I loved reading Roger and Brittany's, Ian's, Lord John's, and William's stories along with Jaime and Claire's in Echo. The only thing I don't like is the four year wait between novels. I always tell myself I'm going to read slowly and savor her novels but then can't sleep or do anything else until I finish them. My two favorite books so far are this one and Voyager but they all deserve 5+ stars IMO and don't read them out of order or you will not get the effect of following them on their journey and lives through time. Best Books Ever!

This series has been wonderful. It keeps me interested throughout each book. Each book sees the reader through different periods of history. I am of Scottish descent and it has been especially interesting regarding the Scots angle. I can hardly wait for the next book to see what happens to all of the characters, especially Roger,Brianna and their family. If you've been reading the series, this book continues the story about Jamie and Claire Frasier. I can't say too much without giving away the plot, but Claire thinks Jamie has drowned and marries Lord John to keep from punishment for "treasonous" acts. All in all, a GREAT book.

Want to read the most unique series of books ever written? Read the Outlander series! History, romance, sci/fi, fantasy, adventure all rolled into one and crammed between 2 covers. Echo In The Bone is book 7 in the series and does not disappoint. Following the lives of married couple Jamie and Clair Fraser as they move through the terror, excitement and confusion of the start of the American Revolutionary War will fill the heart of any history buff with joy. The irony of Clair's foreknowledge when meeting well known Revolutionary figures and her reactions to them on a personal level will tickle anyone's funny bone. Definite classic!

If "Outlander" [book one] is five stars (and it is) then I would have to give "An Echo in the Bone" 4 stars.  It's still a fantastic series (best series I ever read; narrowly edging out the previous number one which is "Clan of the Cave Bear," or the Earth Children series) but, weirdly, I liked the odd number books the best and the even number books have been 4 stars instead of 5.  BUT book 7 is the exception and among the four stars, number 7 was my least favorite.  But, overall, I give books 1-8 FIVE stars and highly recommend it!  Also, on Diana Gabaldon's website, she confirms there will be a book Eight!

I really wanted to like, no, love this book.  But I actually disliked it so much.  The Brianna and Roger parts are boring, as are the Lord John Grey parts.  Jaimie and Claire's relationship, even, has gotten boring.  I guess I'm sick of reading about how huge and strong he is, what sanctuary they are for each other...as if those points weren't made about a gajillion times in all the other books.  I tried three times over a few years, and found the story so unpleasant that I never got past Chapter 9.  It probably gets better.  I just can't hang in there. I think I'll go read the summary on Wikipedia just to find out what happens.

I really enjoyed this book!  The stories of all the characters I have come to love continue to evolve.  There is, as in all of the Outlander series, a great deal of adventure!  There is a good amount of jumping between continents and centuries but I enjoyed the quick shifts.  I was kept thoroughly entertained.  I am so glad I came to this series after it was complete (or at least mostly complete) as the end of each book really leaves you hanging and yearning to know more.  My kindle always gives me the option to immediately purchase the next book in the series and you can bet your bottom dollar I do just that! :)

Will we have to wait for years to get an ending to this book?...I'm a hugh fan but, what? The first 400 or so pages are sleepers, then the 'ending' was so RUSHED! I should have gone back and reread the series before reading this...I had thought with a book this long, and this long in the making there would have been a little more review. All in all, interesting because we are already involved with the characters...but otherwise way too much going on, with a lot of lose ends! And where did all the steaminess go? I miss the old Jamie!

I bought both the book and the Audible edition so that I could go back and forth between audio book and reading with the Whispersync feature.  The book is the 7th in a series and if you are just starting the Outlander series, you MUST continue and get to this book.  The author is so complete in her writing and descriptions and there is so much adventure that even though it is a long book - it is never boring!!  From an audible perspective, I do think that Davina Porter is so very talented and is by far the best readers and her performance is PERFECT!  I audio portion makes a great book even better!

Historical romance with a touch of fantasy/magic realism, handled by a master, this Outlander novel is gripping throughout.  Gabaldon is a marvelous writer who draws both her characters and her place vividly and unforgettably.  You can tell that she has researched the eighteenth century exhaustively; all the little details of daily life ring true. Ditto for the medical passages.  This is no bodice ripper, though the romantic passages put most so-called 'romance' novels to shame.  Even though the books are long, they are gripping and often laugh-out-loud funny.  There hasn't been a dull moment yet.

Diana's first four books were amazing and then they started to slip then the last one got better but was short as if she was floundering to find something to write about. But this book is pure Gold. She didn't try to tell readers who haven't read her books any past history but kept to the new story line and went back and forth smoothly with drama mystery knitting and combining and creating old and new stories so well that it captured you like her first books which wouldn't let you go. Now I'm screaming for her next one. I am 69 year old woman and I think I can say I am very proud of you Diana

A friend recommended that I read Diana Gabaldon Outlander series. I was pleasantly surprised after reading book one. Now that I have finished book seven, I am still thinking about these characters and where the story has just left us off on the cliff. What an amazing journey it has been. Not only a significant part of history, but Ms. Gabaldon weaves a wonderful story through time with colorful and interesting characters. I will definitely be looking for book eight to come out. Do not let the mere 800 plus pages fool you in each novel, as I have loved each and every page of these stories.

I have to agree with the other comments on this book.  This book left too much hanging and its been years waiting for the answers to the cliff hanger.  I am about ready to hang it up because its been so long that I need to go back and re-read this book to remember everything that happened before going on the next book.  And they are much too long to do that.  So it is really annoying that she is writing all these other books about John's story and a bunch of junk instead of writing the next book on Jamie and Claire Frazier.  So frustrating!  You have kept us waiting too long for answers.

I didn't expect this sprawling 'last' book in the series to have all the loose ends tied up neatly in a bow. But the way it "ends" it should have said 'to be continued'! It would have been nice if SOMETHING could have been resolved. And introducing a whole new dilemma for Bree and Roger so late in the book was simply maddening! (that lead wasn't followed again - argh!) I've loved her characters and her storytelling through the entire series, but this one ended more like a cliffhanger leading up to the final episode - not the final episode itself. Diana - please: there has to be one more!

I absolutely positively adore this book! Each page is captivating! This may sound silly but when I have to put it down , ( I do have a family and job that interfere) the characters and story are all I think about . I find myself thinking I have to hurry and get back to them because sometimes I leave them in the middle of extremely difficult situations! I have never fallen in love with fictional characters the way I have these. I feel like they are a part of me ! This is a definite , beyond a shadow of a doubt, no questions asked , hands down, the most phenomenal series I have ever read!

My daughter gave me the first book a few years ago and I was hooked!  I bought the next 6 books all at once, now I just finished reading the series again and I still love it and will definitely read them all again! The only problem I have is how Echo in the bone ended! I want more!!!! Jamie and Claire and their family came alive for me, I was there! Please Ms Gabaldon continue from Echo with as many more as you can write! I don't see how anyone would not love this series, Diana Gabaldon is an excellent story teller, there is action, romance, history and mystery in all her books.

I love Jamie and Claire and all the detail that Diana includes in her books.  The characters seem so real.  This book, more than the others, was a little frustrating at the end because the next one in the series won't be out until Fall 2013 and Echo in the Bone had a number of loose ends not tied up.  You can get a little relief by reading the novella about Roger's parents.  There is a hint in there about one of the loose ends in Echo in the Bone.  And then there are some excerpts from the next book on her website, which relieve some distress caused by the end of this book.

I can't believe all the poor reviews concerning this book.  I am thankful I did not take most of the review advice.  This book is great!!  You have the best of both worlds.  Jamie and Claire are still very much  a part of this book throughout as well as Roger and Brianna.  I love that William has been included more after all he is Jamie's son.  This book does not disappoint.  I am posting my review before being totally finished with the book because of so many negative comments that have been posted.  Oh, and by the way there is a lot of letters and I love those too!.

The continuation of the life adventures of Jamie Fraser and his wife Claire gets more complicated in this book. Alot of new characters and jumping back and forth... both in time and on sides of the war battle being fought in the colonies. While always vivid in her writing, Gabaldon makes you feel like you are there but at times you are not sure where "there" is. I still gave it a 5 star rating for the fact I love the storyline and can't get enough of Jamie, Claire and their family.

Although I like all the books in the series (some much more than others), I confess I have been less than enthralled by the lengthy descrptions of military exploits/intrigue of the last couple novels. I wondered if this series was headed the way of another (formerly) favorite author's series (hint: tedious cave descriptions and recaps). I was joyously surprised with this latest novel in the Outlander series.  It had several OMG plot twists (not gonna spoil them) that had me on the edge of my seat and I am once again EAGERLY awaiting the next installment.

The Outlander series is the best series I've ever read, and this latest book is equally as wonderful.  Jamie and Claire are involved in another set of adventures, while Brianna and Roger are involved in their own years later.  We see more of Jamie's son William in this book as well.  I cannot wait for the next book to come out this coming June!  I highly recommend this series to everyone.  It is full of adventure, action, humor, romance, heart ache and triumph, and everything in between.  It's also fascinating to read about the Revolutionary time period.

I'm not sure why anyone would give any of the books in this series less than a 5!  They are so well written, and this one was as superb as all of the other 6.  This was the 2nd time I've read the last 3 in the series and when book 9 comes out (I am in the process of reading Book 8) I will re-read the last 4 again - there is just so much happening that little details are forgotten and Diana makes sure all of her details are important - you can't afford to forget them because they will for sure show up in the next installment!  Love these - you will too!

Can I just burn this book and pretend it never happened?  I waited so long and this is my reward??!!?  To say I'm disappointed is an understatement.  I'm going to pretend none of this ever happened.  Rats on you, Diana Gabaldon.  I thought you were my friend.

As a female physician and as an avid reader, I must say I really enjoy her work. Forget the writing of some of the most popular authors - they are rather boring and predictable compared to Gabaldon's writing and prose. I'm happy that Jamie and Claire aren't killed off yet and that evidently another book is coming. The historical setting is fascinating and helps put our modern days troubles into perspective.

I have recently reread the whole series and I can honestly say the author has not missed a step with this book. The characters stay true and yet they grow. I love the slight fantasy mixed in with the gritty reality of the American Revolution. I love the expanded role of Jamie's son William and even though I wasn't quite as interested in John Grey and the spy stuff it was a small enough part of the book I was willing to accept it as necessary to the story as a whole. I can't wait for the next book (and I have no doubt there will be a next book!).

This novel is part of the Outlander series.  Absolutely the best series I have ever had the pleasure to read.  I read the first book many years ago when it was first published and I enjoyed it at the time but there was no sequel to it then.  A few years later some friends of mine were talking about this wonderful series of books that I should read.  To my surprise, it was the on going story of Claire and Jamie that I had loved.  I have since then read all of the series and re-read them over and over. I highly recommend this series to everyone.

I am now reading the eighth book of The Outlander and amazed with the author.  How she can create so many different scenes for so many characters is mind boggling!  I am late a lot because I don't want to stop reading.  Must finish the chapter.  Trying to figure where she will go with the story.  It is the most wonderful, powerful love story I have ever read.  I don't want it to end.  The history of the time it is written is indescribablle.  The horror of the way the wounded was treated .  Thank God for modern medicine  This is a must read.

Having just returned from Scotland I am reading the series again from the beginning and feel like I am there!  Walking the fields of Cullodeon knowing this battle really took place and I could be standing on someone's remains gives a real sense of living history.  The visitors center has an amazing 360 degree exhibit having pictures as well as sound of what the battle could have sounded like!  Gabledon's writing is gripping and conquers historical fiction.  Given each book is over 700 pages, I am still enthralled the second time around!

Another fabulous book in the Outlander series.  So glad the next book is available (Written in My Own Heart's Blood) so I can pick right up and continue with the story line.  For all those who haven't read this series of books, do yourself a favor and start  - "Outlander" is the first book.  One of the best series of books ever - Diana Gabaldon is truly a gifted writer who weaves a great story line into well researched historical events.  Each book is rather long so reading on my Kindle has been much kinder on my arms  :)

Having now completed seven out of Gabadon's eight Outlander books, I continue to feel enamored but also very exhausted. For me books 1-3 were the best....4 was a bit of a let down but like a well written daytime soap opera, gave continuance to the story of Jamie and Claire et al. I am satiated at this moment and don't feel ready to move on the book 8 for a while. There are quite a few cliff hangers from book 7 that will be resolved in the next book, but I can wait to see how DG rectifies the lives of the Outlander characters.

Lastest in the Outlander Series.  Diana Gabaldon makes the characters come to life.  I feel that Jamie, Claire, Brianna, Roger are like family and I want the series to go on forever.  I will be greatly disappointed if this is the end.  Even though the books are quite long (800-1000 Pages), I never want them to end.  There's time travel, adventure and unforgettable characters who have come a long way.  They are in the beginning of the Revolutionary War in America in this book.  You definitely need to read the books in order.

I've made it through the first 7 books in the series in two months.  Echo was excellent.  Have already started book 8.  Not sure what I'll do when I finish it.  I've become very engrossed in the Outlander books, and appreciate the historical fiction as well as the remarkable characters.  Several events from the period of the revolution have come up in other contexts of late, and was surprised how much the books added to my understanding of the period.  Highly recommend the entire series.  Gabaldon has a great writing style.

wonderful continuing story from the first book- Overlander, to the seventh - An Echo in the Bone- only one final book in the series left to read- each book provides the reader with historical insight reflecting the times the story takes place, written in the very personal context of a family who struggle on a day to day basis, managing through strong family bonds to meet adversity together. It is a true love story between Claire, who is from the 20th century & Jamie, from the 1700's. Every woman needs a Jamie in her life!

Once again, this author has carried me down the path of imagination, adding twists and turns that I never would've thought of. Of course, my one complaint is that it's always far too long between stories. Now that the next book is coming into site, I have reread the entire series. Unfortunately, I have finished too soon and still have a month to wait. What a great cliffhanger! This is one of the only authors whose works I will purchase at full price, rather than wait for the prices to drop. I think that says it all.

I spend a lot of time reading due to my health and a good story helps to distract me from pain and discomfort.  A GREAT story takes me away from myself for awhile and allows me a small window of comfort.  Diana Gabaldon's  Outlander stories have always provided me with that window.  I look forward to each new book  as much as I mourn coming to the end of one.  Even  when I am not reading one I am wondering what is going to happen next or going over what I last read, fixing it in my mind like a scene from a movie.

I'm still in love with these books! Since I'm reading them start to finish (8 books) I'm really ready to read something new, but now that I'm getting ready to start the last book I'm thinking I will really miss Jamie and Claire and the rest of the characters!  I read recently that DG is writing #9 but it won't be out for another year or so.  As always, this book has no shortage of action...love, war, murder, sickness, Indians, Scots, British, time travel...and everything in between! Thoroughly enjoyable to me...

This continuation of the story of Claire and Jamie Frazier took me back to the excitement and anticipation that I felt reading "Outlander".  It gave me many moments of joy and laughter as the character revealed even more of their senses of humor and wit.  My most favorite parts were the absolutely wonderful letters from Claire and Jamie to Briana, and Lord John"s letters to his brother and his son.  I highly recommend this book to all the fans of Ms Gaboldon and her "Outlander "series.

I read all the reviews before I purchased the book, and just didn't believe they could be true, I mean as someone who has read and re-read the series so many times, (yearly) it was not a question of "IF" I would read the book, just when.  I did not mind the numerous story lines, we need to catch up with everyone, and yes, some of it was a bit slow, but again, alot to catch up on. But being left in what felt like mid sentence at the end? My question is how soon will the "next" chapter come out......

Just a wonderful as all the other Outlander series books! Has it all! I mean I wish there weren't so many characters so we can just get down to what we all really want, a book all about Jamie, but this book is wonderful still. Buy it! If you have not read any of the other books then start on Outlander now! You will be glad you did. Also I hope you have a lot of reading time on your hands because these books are a wonderful adventure that you can't get enough of.I highly recommend the whole series!

Great story of life.  Jamie and Claire continue with everyday life in a time of transition and change.  Family growing up and new exposure of different ideals make life a little more challenging.  Series is long but the span is a life time.  Very enjoyable for what it is and a very good read.  I simply love all the ups and downs and have started my last Outlander Book 8.  I will be very sad for this to come to an end.  Only bright side is the Mini Series on TV will begin again on April 8, 2015.

Love the Claire & Jamie characters but this truly should have been a trilogy. The story is just okay ... although rather slow. Ms. Gabaldon builds up in the final chapters to leave you hanging so that you'll get the next book. Which by this time you're so invested in Jamie & Claire that you will wait for that next book. I'm so thankful for e-Library so that I don't have to buy the book or borrow from the library and be forced to carry around a book that's thicker than pre-internet phone book.

Love this series! Almost finished with the eighth book now. The only reason I give this one four stars is that it leaves so many loose ends. Perhaps Diana knows that by the time you read the eighth book, you'll surely go on to read the next one?  I had to laugh when Jamie finally says, "Jesus H. Roosevelt Christ," in this book. If you've ever been married a long time, you have to appreciate that, even though, in this instance, Jamie may have no appreciation for who Roosevelt might be.

All these books are great! Very detailed and lengthy at times, which slows the flow. But this book is a prelude to the next and makes it most important to read. Diana is an awesome author who does the research well, and a hard act to follow while waiting for each book in the series. Love her style and added humor! This is good historical reading and fast pace, and will leave you wanting more. Very addictive! I'm definitely an outlandish fan!! Keep it coming - through the stones and years!

I enjoyed the book very much. I had put off reading it due to some disappointing reviews, but was pleasantly surprised. The ending is a bit of a cliff hanger, but that leads me to believe that there must be something more comming. Who the books focus will be remains to be seen. But I'd be very surprised if after 6 books and many years, that Diana Gabaldon would leave her fans/readers in limbo. Thanks Diana

The Outlander cast weaves through a more familiar history with the coming of the American Revolution.  Family ties line up on either side of the conflict and the strong pull from Scotland urges those past and present back to the family compound. Roger and Bree's dislocation felt a bit forced and not as satisfying as some of the other plot lines but Young Ian shines here.  Overall, quite enjoyable and oh so comfortable.  Now a short wait for the next installment in June 2014....

There no real ending with so much left unanswered.  Perhaps her latest book won't leave us hanging so loosely/ she is a great writer/ after heard the previous statement about this book by so many others I really enjoyed the book. I don't think would have had I not been given the "heads up" on the "unanswered" situation. I would still recommend the book to others as she is still a great writer. I didn't give it a 5 rating because of so many unanswered questions.

Just to start, I love this series. Been one of my all time favorites. However, it should have ended at book six. Book seven is long, convoluted, and an effort to read. Too many unimportant characters, too many twists in the plot and just plain confusing......so I lost interest. I'll admit I only made it through 60% of the book, but I couldn't take it anymore. It's time for these senior citizens to hang it up and retire. I'll have to catch up with their lives with Cliff notes.

I'm a little sad because this is the last of the Outlander series. It's been wonderful. The historical research for this series has pushed me to get some non-fiction books......specifically a history of the Highlanders in the 1700's and Revolutionary War books. I appreciate reading fiction that also informs me and educates me, historically. This series has done it well. I like to read well written books and this series also fits the bill. Thanks for the ride, Diana Gabaldon!

Diana Gabaldon's epic series narrating the adventures of James and Claire Fraser, et.al. is a rare achievement: its detailed historical accuracy and insight into nature (human, biological and botanical) are raw and robust, leaving this reader simply aching for the next installment ("Written in My Heart's Blood"), while tossing aside less complex novels as mundane. Having taught writing and literature for 40 years, I'm impressed by the author's depth and breadth!

I love this series.  I had the most trouble making my way through this one more than the previous six.  I think because the story is broken up following several characters in more than one time period it was less addictive.  As the book was wrapping up, the characters were coming together geographically and their stories started to connect.  It was worth charging through the less interesting parts to get to the end.  As with all these good, still great story telling.

This book just continues the story of Jamie and Claire and their family.  I would, however, suggest that if you decide to read "An Echo in the Bone: that you start with the first book in the entire series, although in reality any of the books in this series could stand alone.  I don't usually get caught up in such an extensive series but for some reason it has captured my interest.  I am now reading the last of the Outlander Series and will be sad for it to end.

Another great book in the Outlander series; did not want the story to end.  Diana Gabaldon writes in such a way that you can't help but be drawn into the story line, become a part of the characters lives, and the history of the time comes to life because of the way she weaves it throughout each book.  When I read the book, I would only read a couple of pages a day thinking it might be her last book (did not want it to end).  So happy to be reading her new book now!

I love every single one of the Outlander Series books  I have read and re-read the entire series multiple times.  The books are well written.  You care about what happens to the characters and can not wait for the next book to come out to see what happens next.  The research Diana Gabaldon has done is makes the books so realistic you almost believe that if you should accidentally travel back in time you would have the skills to survive as well as Jaime and Claire.

Again, I was impressed that Dr. Fraser could carry out surgery in the primitive circumstances of the 18th century. She was able to concoct ether and to grow penicillin from bread mold. She accomplished an appendectomy as well as numerous other operations with the help of laudanum and liquor.The action-packed plot made the pages hard to put down. Most of the action took place in North Carolina with side trips to the mohawk village where Ian married an Indian girl.

This is the 8th in the Outlander series by Diana Gabaldon. The first is now on Starz TV and millions are addicted to the book series before the series went on TV. Historically correct as much as possible, you'll find yourself in a meeting with General Washington and and Benedict Arnold. Claire fell through the stones and time in Outlander and ere she is in America before and during the Revolution. You will fall in love with Jaime and Claire and their family.

First let me say that I LOVE the Outlander series, however this was the hardest book for me to get in to. On average the other books took me two weeks to read, this one took me two months. It picked up in the last quarter of the book & I found I couldn't put it down for the last 150 pages. It is definitely an essential read to continue the series & MOBY has taken up right where this one leaves off. Maybe a re-read is what I need to change my average rating.

I didn't like this or Book 8 as much as I did the others.  There are long periods spent away from Jamie & Claire focusing on other characters & events I don't care all that much about.  I'm sure a lot of time & effort went into researching all of that but what I enjoy is Jamie & Claire's life as well as that of their immediate family.  Sometimes there were 100 pgs or more on others.  Once she got back to them again I liked it so I was eafer to read Book 8.

This entire series has been an adventure. Just as I thought all was settled something new would occur.  Some parts of the story(s) were more detailed than I enjoy and I found myself skimming through them. The core of the story, however, was compelling and I could barely close the reader! I have been exposed to a ton of new vocabulary making me thankful for my electronic dictionary. The core story has left me hanging and I can't wait to see what is next.

This author continues to provide a quality read. The length of her book(s) is not a deterrent as her writing is crisp and imaginative.My finding a female author who appeals to and captures my interest is often a challenge, but Ms. Gabaldon has been a great find! Good literature is just that, no matter the gender of the author, and to me she proves the point. I will be sorry to see the series end, and I thank my daughter for introducing me to this read.

I love The Outlander series. I am not 100% pleased with the packaging, as it seems there is excess glue in the paper sleeves where the discs go. . . and several discs have glue on them. Thankfully it's just on the edge, and wipes off and has not interfered with playing. I have not gotten to the end,. . . but cant wait, as I have read other reviews. (However, I have read the summary for the next book to be released in 2014, and it was too descriptive!)

In anticipation of the release of the next book on June 10, I had to reread this so I would not forget all that was going on. I enjoyed it more the second time around...perhaps I get lost sometimes remembering who is who since there is always so much going on. I really can't add anymore to what has already been said  about this series.. start at the beginning, keep a log of characters and who they are related to and plan on reading every free moment.

ANOTHER of Gabaldon's wonderful series. I have been reading each in order, and staying up 'til all hours, missing sleep until I finish one chapter, then just one more,etc. Missing g some of my favorite tv shows _ putting off bought DVD movies because yet another chapter or Outlander book was waiting. And the  sense of being at Culloden, then the Revolutionary War was  so realistic. The research must have been exhausting. You must read them all!!!!!,

I buy the next book in the series as soon as I finish the last page of the previous book - this book was no different.  Just relieved that Diana Gabaldon had JUST published "Written in my own heart's blood" when I finished "An Echo in the Bone".  Good thing....I didn't know what I was going to do with myself after submerging myself into the Outlander series for the past year!  An Echo in the Bone was just as good as all the rest : )

I love long books full of interesting stories and Diana Gabaldon never disappoints.  I did become a little impatient with this one--sometimes lost the characters and had to go back to research (hurray for Kindles and iPads) and sometimes thought a few incidents didn't add to the totality of the book.  However, the history is fascinating and the main characters are very likable and interestimg.  Will continue to read them as long as she writes them.

The perfect last book in the series. It is well written within the American historic content. The character development is done in a way that feels right. To have come through Jamie and Claire's entire married life, with all its hardships but also with its joys and happiness in having a soul mate with whom to share your life, is very fulfilling. Yeah for the family reunion. Everything worked out as it should have.Enjoyed this series tremendously.

Seventh book in the wonderful "Outlander" series written by award winning author Diana Gabaldon. Come with Jamie, Claire, Brianna, Roger, Ian and all the inhabitants of Fraser's Ridge as they romp in and out of the 18th and 20th centuries. Love, hate, birth & death.....they do it all!  Oh, by the way, there's this thing called The American Revolutionary War as a backdrop. No spoilers here - just read the books, you won't be disappointed.

I first listened to this series several years ago (all of the available books at the time) but recently, when the newest book came out, I decided to actually read the books to review the story and the cast of characters.  I'm glad I did.  I found that I missed so much by just listening.  And then, too, I'm older, have had more experiences, and so I have picked up details I know wouldn't have meant much the first time around.  I love this series.

I do like this series.  I have been with Claire and Jaime for several years.  The ending of this book seemed rushed to me.  So many events of the past and current books have detailed descriptions.  As the ending neared, it just seemed to happen and then the chapter went to another subject. The story was told and satisfying and I will purchase the next book.  I just felt that someone else wrote the ending.  It was not Ms. Gabaldon's usual style.

This book, like all the other Outlander Series is terrific!  My frustration is that this time, Diana left us hanging with many things unresolved.  Since it takes her upwards of 5 years to publish the next book in the series, that is really frustrating!  All the other books in the series came to a conclusion and still left you wanting to read the next one, so why do this to her readers when she doesn't produce books any faster than she does?!?

I love Jaime and Claire. Love this series!!! I hope she writes twenty more books and I've already preordered her next book. I've read and reread the series multiple times. She, Mary Stewart, and Rowling are in a class all by themselves.  If you are new to the world of Jamie and Claire, welcome to the magic.  There are not enough words to praise this enduring work of art.  Thank you, Ms Gabaldon.  Claire is a role model for women everywhere.

I have loved the entire Outlander series and this one is especially good.  Since it was to be the last I was disappointed that it was the end of the series and when I got to the end I was sad, only to find out that the next book was out and the excerpt at the end of the book was a continuation.  There were loose pieces to be closed.  I went out and bought the next Kindle book "My Own Heart's Blood" which I will be anxious to read.

This is a wonderful continuation of the series, with finally (spoiler alert) someone who travels the other way and a cliff hanging ending.  The device of letters is perhaps used too much, but they are also interesting. It's an additional dimension to capture a character's writing style as well.  Claire's to Brianna were much more fun, but Willam's and John's were probably much more typical of the age. I want more...now...but have to wait.

I would have preferred  less time spent on the battles and more on the last part of the book.  There are just too many hanging threads and given the length of time between novels it is quite frustrating.  I wish Ms. Gabaldon wrote a smaller novel each year, rather than a tome every 3 to 4 years.

I thought this book was quite excellent. Yes, a lot of new characters are introduced, but what do you expect when you're this far into a series? And all the new "loose ends" that were introduced just leave me hope that there will be many more books to come! It was really excellent job, and I'm so glad to have read it. I can't wait until the newest one comes in December so I can have an excuse to reread the whole series. ;-)

Since I have read all of the other "Outlander" series, I was anxiously awaiting the release of this one and I haven't been disappointed.  Never thought I would care for a book about time travelers but I am hooked.  Gabaldon has woven her story in with the historical events so expertly that I almost believe that it is possible.  I am nearing the end and feel like I don't want it to end.  Hope there is another book to come.

A shorter read, but none the less, her miner conflicts and their resolutions are as enthralling and true to the enticing developments and conclusions as her previous novels.  I especially appreciate the length and complexity of this series.  Having researched her characters and facts, I find her accurate in their presentations and enjoy the enlightenment.  Benjamin Franklin's frequent air-bathing in the nude was quite startling!

I put off reading this due to the previous reviews.  But, finally tackled it because I love the characters.  And I loved it!  I thought that the twists and turns were great!  It starts from the prospective of William ( Jaimy's son) and therefore is slightly confusing, but then picks up and never stops.  I actually read this much faster than the others.  Don't be discouraged by the reviews, I am anxiously awaiting the next one!!!

holy crap - WHAT COMES NEXT?? luckily, i'm behind the times so i don't have to wait 3 years to find out. :) i'm still really looking forward to the next one. as all the outlander books, this one takes a while to get good (maybe the first 10-15%), but once it does, it takes off at a crazy pace. i'm loving this series (and on an audio book related note: davinia porter is an EXCELLENT narrator - i will buy anything she narrates).

I'll just go ahead and admit that I'm hooked on these characters, as outrageous as some of their adventures seem to be....but it's not boring with this family for sure, I recommend reading them in order. I bought one book at the airport a few years ago, not realizing it was a series so I read the first few not in order...I will probably go back and read them again sometime. Entertaining if you love historical fiction as I do.

Maybe it should have been 2 novelettes, but whatever, I am glad Diana Gabaldon writes her books.  I admire her depiction of the characters and the land of Scotland.  I was reminded of books by an other author about the settling of North Carolina.  History.  I have my good days and so do authors.  Let's give her a breathing space!  I added this book to my shelf with the hope we will get more from the author.  Thank you Diana.

As always Diana Gabaladon transports the reader to the past in waves of color, emotion and love. As a Tidewater Virginia resident I am always enthralled by her descriptive narrative of the area. I have been to The Great Dismal Swamp and can see it the way it was too hundred years ago in her book. I have become a die hard fan and cherish her books reading them like a fine wine or chocolate, small amounts so that it lasts.

Diana Gabaldon can do no wrong in my opinion but I keep wondering if there will ever be an end to the saga.  Her descriptive writing gives you the feeling of being present during the adventures,  I am a little curious about the sexual habits of some of the characters but not having lived in those times I guess I could tolerate having sex without taking a bath for a couple of weeks.  Am already ordering the next book.

I have a love hate relationship with these books.  I read one and say to myself, that's it!  A month goes by, and I need to know what's happening with Jamie and Claire. I just need to know. So I BUY the next book. I had an uncle like this. He was really irritating after a few days, but I couldn't wait to see him on his next visit. I have to say I really like this story, and in all honesty I can't wait for the sequel.

As always I enjoy Diana Gabaldon's books, her characters and historical finess.  I have reread her books at least 6 times and keep them on my Kindle and I paper form when there isn't anything interesting to read.. I believe this book was rushed and chopped up.. A lot of story lines running together to tidy up the ending to make another book.. I am alway for another book .. And I know it has to end at some point ...

I HAVE REREAD HER FIRST SIX NOVELS - SOME OF THEM THREE TIMES.  WONDERFUL AUTHOR WHO HAS MADE ME GO BACK TO CHECK SOME OF THE HISTORICAL FACTS IN HER BOOKS.  IT IS AMAZING HOW SHE CAN DRAW YOU IN, MAKE YOU RECHECK HISTORY AND ENJOY THE SEXUAL ASPECTS OF HER BOOKS WITHOUT FEELING SLEAZY.  SHE IS ONE OF MY FAVORITES.  NOW TV HAS DISCOVERED THE OUTLANDER SERIES!!! I HOPE THE TV SERIES STAYS TRUE TO HER WRITING STYLE.

every book in this series leaves me wanting the next one. Gallatin does a terrific job building characters.And there are a lot of characters so it's good they're interesting! Jamie and Claire have the kind of relationship every woman wants - total respect for the gifts and talents of the other and total acceptance of the other's human foibles and frailties. Start from book one in the series. You won't regret it.

As with the other books in this series, the vivid descriptions allow you to feel a part of the ongoing story. The author expertly weaves the individual threads of the many beloved and not so beloved characters, diverse locations and times into a tapestry of beauty, suspence and the brutal realities of war. I am anxious to read the next book but also hesitant to start knowing that it is the last in the series

I am addicted to this series and have read them several times. Have them on my Kindle and can go round and round. Currently reading this book again and am so sorry the 8th book is so slow to come out. As usual the story is action packed, but this one takes us back and forth between centuries. The contact between Clair and Jamie with Briana and Roger is fascinating. AND the end leaves the reader up in arms.

I have most if not all of the books in this series.  This book continues the story filling in memory gaps from earlier books more than adequately.  Probably because I read this one as an e-Book, this one seemed to be extremely long ending rather abruptly.  The preview of the next book in the series did help to fill in some of the gaps, but obviously I will need to read the next book for the whole story.

You won't be disappointed, another hit with Diana doing what she does best. I was blessed when a friend shared this series with me later on (October 2012) since then I have read the entire series 1-8, two times and it's just a magical the second time around. I wonder how many more times I will read this until we are blessed by her hard work and dedication in Book 9, that she's already creating for us.

If you've read any of the Outlander series, you'll read this book anyway. If you haven't, what are you waiting for? Start at the beginning. This series is the most delicious mind candy, and frankly, I think this book ranks among her best. Please don't ever quit writing, Diana. These characters have become my friends. I have never been much of a fan of anybody, but I am a devoted fan of Diana Gabaldon.

The adventure, suspense, romance, science fiction with a little bit of history... Diana Gabaldon never disappoints.  I have now read every book in the Outlander series and anxiously await the next book.  The stories are long... It makes for fun times in the gym.  I have logged in record hours exercising and spending many calories, all while getting lost in the stories about Jamie Fraser and family.

Can't wait for book 9  Even though there is sexual content, it is between spouses in almost all cases. I learned a lot of historical events & settings. She does a great deal of description. She develops the characters in depth. She has a vast biblical knowledge which she interweaves throughout the book, but not at all "preachy." These comments are applicable to the entire Outlander series.

The 7th book in the Outlander series - this installment didn't disappoint! And I finished it just in time to start Diana Gabaldon's new book "Written in my Own Heart's Blood", which is #8. I highly recommend reading the series in order, starting with "Outlander". It has everything - history, time travel, romance, fascinating characters, adventure, and it's extremely well-written!

A roller-coaster novel that leaves you dreaming for the next book. Fortunately Written in my Own Heart's Blood is coming soon. I enjoyed it more in this re-read because I hadn't the anxiety of first time reading, and Diana's detailed and powerful writing deserves to be enjoyed leisurely. And listening to Davina Porter's audio is an additional treat! As all Diana's novels, re-reading is a must!

I have been hooked since the first book in the Outlander series.  Several of my friends are onboard too.  Gabaldon's words are wonderful, the plots ( and there are many) are exciting and mixed with history and romance......  I think it is best to read the books in sequence as there is always reference to a previous character, or incident.  I always look forward to the next book in the series.

Another great book in the series.  I have been rereading all of the Outlander books in the past 2 weeks (7,605 pages!!) and only have 200 to go in MOBY.  Love these books.  The characters are fabulous.  I am an avid reader and these are my most favorite books.  Just sad that I will have to wait 2-3 years now for the next installment.  Highly, highly recommend these.  The defy description!

A few years ago I read the 1st 2 books in this series, decided to re-read them on kindle.  I was thrilled to see that there were others.  So, I just finished reading the entire series, finishing this one on Saturday.  Wow.  As always the writing and story are well done, I feel as if all these characters are family members.  I am glad I don't have to wait too long to find out what happens!

This series keeps getting more and more absorbing!  I love the physical descriptions of the landscapes and immediate environment of Claire and her family and feel often like I could close my eyes and almost be there.  Having aging protagonists is a big plus too.  Although I was somewhat uncomfortable when reading vol. 1 because I couldn't genre-place it, I'm now addicted.  On to vol. 8!

This is the best series I have ever read and I am an avid reader. I have been reading this particular series for the last 25 years and waited anxiously  for each new book to be released. I have re-read the entire series 3 times. I would recommend this series who enjoys books that are well written and full of excitement. it really is like visiting old friends for me. Just Fabulous!!!!

I read her books when they were originally published, listened to them recently on Audible, then bought some paperbacks on Amazon. I often re-read them and still get caught up in the majesty of her writing. Her character leap off the pages and into your heart and soul. I am always sad when I finished the last one again and can not wait for her newest that comes out in June 2014.

I was never good at history in school. I love the (almost) Historically correct novels that help me to actually learn American history. This one is spell binding. I'm  almost disappointed that there is only one more book. The "F" word has come up more and more in the last couple of books, much to my disappointment. Surely it doesn't have to be used so much to make a good story!

A sweeping novel, historical accuracy and a sweet love story which criss-crosses the centuries. You get to really care about the protagonists whose characterisations are superb, they are believable people who you'd like to know.  I know it's been written for an American audience but I really don't like the American spellings which I suspect, given the time frame is inaccurate.

It is so hard to stop reading this ongoing story of the lives of the characters in these books.  I find myself going back to some of the previous stories to remind myself how this all fits in together.  Definitely one to keep your interest in who and what is going on.  I cannot imagine where the story line for these books will go next, much less just keep up.  Great reads!!!

This book is a really great read for excitement and adventure, with some history thrown in. The series doesn't fail to entertain and the only down part is that they don't number the books so it's easy to accidentally read them out of order and then be confused. But do read these books, they're wonderful, just be ready to keep track of who is who and where and when they are.

Somewhat different then the first 6 books.  There were so many different events going on with so many different characters.  There was a lot of skipping back and forth through time as well.  It was a little confusing for a while.  Events did come together at the end but there are certainly a lot of cliffhangers.  Definitely need to read the next book to get the outcomes.

Beginning with Diana Gabaldon' s first Outlander Series novel, I fell in love with her writing, her characters, her research, and her books.  This most recent (to date) has proved to be no less captivating than the 6 novels  that in this series that preceded An Echo In The Bone.  I eagerly am anticipating Book #8, Written In My Own Hearts Blood, coming out later in 2013.

If anyone feels a void in their romantic life this is the book for you.  I think we all long for a life partner one who will adore us forever, give their very life for you. One who thinks we are beautiful and says so every now and then Regardless of how we age. Now that's love, that is what I long to hear. So glad I found thts series. So it's on to the next book. Yippee

By now I'm hooked.  I must find out what happens to these characters I've grown to know and love.  The have become a part of my life.  Action picked up near the end of the book setting in motion all kinds of possibilities.  I love the way Jamie and Claire's relationship has changed but remained the same.  Love the sense of family and what that means to the characters.

Once again the author does not disappoint. Our main characters, Jamie and Claire Fraser are immersed in the turmoil and hardships of the Revolutionary War while we simultaneously learn the fate of Brianna and Roger who have successfully returned to the twentieth century. A fun and fascinating read for Outlander junkies (like myself) who have loved the first six books.

It's taken me ages, it seems, to get to this point in the series but I'm glad I finally made it.  I read all the previous books as they came out I was so eager to read them and now that Outlander is on Starz TV my interest has been more than "renewed".  I also have "Written in My Own Heart's Blood" that came out this summer and will be reading it soon.

to find out what will happen to the lives of the characters who now are part of my mental life...life changing,gripping,thrusting time forward and back ,entwining history and making the whole vision of the scenery,smells, even the taste of the times..enflaming each of the five senses to the maximum ,,but the sense of true unbridled love is the strongest in these books

This seventh novel on Diana Gabaldon' s Outlander world keeps the amazing adventures of Jamie and Claire, Brianna, Roger, Jem and Mandy, Ian, Lord John and William, alive; all who share equal time and who come together amidst the Revolutinary War.  And once again, Diana Gabaldon doesn't disappoint, as she weaves their incredible journeys with both tears and laughter.

This Outlander book 7 has lots of action and adventures in America's struggles to oust British control. I learned so much more about the American Revolution than I ever learned in school, seeing it all through the perspective of characters on both sides. Very impressive research was done here, as in all of the Gabaldon's series. Keep reading. Book 8 is exciting too.

An Echo in the Bone is an exciting book with lots of historical detail. Gabaldon plants complicated plot twists to keep the action lively. While the main characters grow older, other characters begin to mature to take their place. If you enjoy American Revolution history, this book has plenty of it. I highly recommend this installment of Gabaldon's Outlander series.

She has but amazed me once again.  To twist a rich history into fiction in such a way, is simply magical.  I don't know why she tried to scare the shot right out of Claire though. The new characters we meet here are wonderfully made (Rachel and Denny Hunter), and twist up Roger and Brianna and their mess, oh ok can't stop reading!  Gotta start the last book NOW!!!

This book is one of the best in the series. I have to say that I loved them all. The author tells a good story that makes you want to read more. Great historical fiction, with adventure and romance. A bright, intelligent heroine and a hero that is everything a woman would ever want in a man.  Love the Outlander series. Start with the first and read them in order.

I'm not sure how others find these books slow to start and choppy, and don't like like  cliff hangers. I love each and every book  of the outlanders....Have read them around 8 times each and am waiting on pins and needles for the next one out  at the end of this year......For you who might wonder....yes I do read other things...like working toward my Masters..

I have been hooked on this series of books since I read the first Outlander novel. This one was rather slow going at first. In fact the first 60% of the book was a rather tedious but important set up for that last 40%. And since I am not a revolutionary war buff the names and locations of people and places was a little confusing. The back 40 was excellent!

I began reading this series years ago and I eagerly anticipate each new novel. Diana Gabaldon is one of the best writers of historical fiction EVER. These are amazing novels -- literally transplanting you to a different time and place. This latest does not disappoint. I keep hoping Hollywood catches on and we get another wonderful series a la J.R. Tolkien.

The entire series of Outlander books are just magnificent. I've been an avid reader for over 50 years and my fav genre is historical fiction. I've become very invested in all the beloved characters in these books! I hope I live long enough to see how it all ends, not knowing how many more books Diana Gabaldon plans to write before it's all said and done!

This the 7th in a series of books chronicling the lives and times of a Scottish Highlander and a time traveler flows like a story of old friends.  This cliff hanging adventure is intertwined with characters that passionately live their lives committed to friends, family, love and monumental change.  I will miss them desperatly until book 8 is released.

I love all the Outlander books! I am a great fan of historical novels and these are especially well done with the 'travelers' [I am not a spoiler]. The book's epilogue talks about readers who turn to maps and history books as they read. I am one of those. Fiction brings history to life and part of the fun is fact checking to learn more about the past.

She just keeps on giving us the best story I have read in a long time. I am going to have to buy the Lord John Grey series now because I just can't get enough of Ms Gabaldons writing. She keeps me so involved in the characters lives that I can see and almost feel what is happening to them.  I laugh out loug, cry and smile a lot when reading her books.

I agree with other comments; too much historical detail & too many loose ends.  I LOVE learning history this way, through historical fiction, but this one was just too ponderous.
